Interest on the Fixed Rate Notes will be paid semi-annually in arrears on and of each year, beginning on, 2018. The Fixed Rate Notes will mature on, 2024.

related fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Financing (as defined herein), including fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Offering. See “Use of Proceeds”.

amount of the Fixed Rate Notes with the net proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to % provided that at least 50% of the original aggregate principal

Fixed Rate Notes, upon not less than 10 nor more than 60 days’ notice, at the applicable redemption price set forth in this offering memorandum. In addition, prior to
, 2020, the Issuer may redeem, during each twelve-month period commencing with the Issue Date, up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the Fixed Rate Notes
outstanding (including Additional Notes, if any), at its option, at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount of the Fixed Rate Notes redeemed plus accrued and unpaid

Prior to, 2018, the Issuer may redeem all or part of the Floating Rate Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest
and additional amounts, if any, plus the applicable “make whole” premium, as described herein. At any time on and after, 2018, the Issuer will be entitled at its option to redeem
all or a portion of the Floating Rate Notes, upon not less than 10 nor more than 60 days’ notice, at the applicable redemption price set forth in this offering memorandum.
The Issuer may redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes upon the occurrence of certain changes in applicable tax law. Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change

The Notes will be the Issuer’s senior obligations and (a) on the Issue Date, will be guaranteed by the Parent Guarantor; (b) on the Completion Date, will be guaranteed by Bidco,

guarantee those obligations or liabilities which, if guaranteed, will constitute an infringement of Spanish financial assistance laws in accordance with Articles 143.2 and 150 of the

On the Issue Date, the Notes and the Note Guarantees will be secured by a first-ranking pledge over the Escrow Account (as defined below). On the Completion Date and upon the
release of the proceeds of the Offering from the Escrow Account, the Notes and the Note Guarantees will be secured on a first-ranking basis by (a) a pledge over all of the issued shares
in the Parent Guarantor; and a pledge over intercompany loan agreements between MEIF 5 Arena Ventures S.à r.l. and the Parent Guarantor; (b) a pledge over bank accounts of the
Parent Guarantor; a pledge over all of the issued shares in Bidco; and a pledge over intercompany loan agreements between Parent Guarantor and Bidco; (c) a pledge over bank

security in this paragraph (d) will be provided within five business days of conversion), collectively, the “Completion Date Collateral”. Within two Business Days of the Completion Date,
the Notes and the Note Guarantees will be secured on a first-ranking basis by all of the issued and outstanding shares of Empark provided Bidco has been converted into a sociedad
_anónima on or before the Completion Date (and, if Bidco has not been converted into a sociedad anónima by the Completion Date, the security in this paragraph will be provided within_

shares of Sociedad Municipal de Aparcamientos y Servicios, S.A.; and 43.0% of the issued and outstanding shares of Estacionamientos Urbanos de Leon, S.A., (b) an account pledge

Date Collateral, the “Collateral”). The security over the Collateral will be limited as necessary to recognize certain limitations arising under or imposed by local law and defenses generally
available to providers of Collateral (including those that relate to fraudulent conveyance or transfer, voidable preference, financial assistance, corporate purpose or benefit, capital
maintenance or similar laws, regulations or defenses affecting the rights of creditors generally) or other considerations under applicable law. In particular, (a) security over the Collateral
granted by Empark, Dornier and Infraestructuras will be limited to the value of the Debt Repayment Proceeds Loan (which is expected to be approximately €424.0 million), and will not

Repayment Proceeds Loan. For a brief description of such limitations, see “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes—Certain of the Note Guarantees will be limited to a specified
_amount, and each Note Guarantee will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable laws or subject to certain defenses that may limit its validity and_
_enforceability” and “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Collateral and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations”._
The Notes and the Note Guarantees will be secured by first-ranking security interests over substantially the same assets that secure the Revolving Credit Facility (as defined herein).
See “Summary—The Offering—Collateral”. The Revolving Credit Facility and certain hedging obligations will be secured on a “super priority” basis and in the event of enforcement of the
Collateral, the holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from the Collateral only after the lenders under the Revolving Credit Facility and counterparties to certain hedging obligations
have been repaid in full. See “Description of Notes—Security”.
Pending completion of the Acquisition (the “Completion Date”), the Issuer will direct the Initial Purchasers (as defined herein) to deposit the gross proceeds from the Offering into escrow
accounts for each of the proceeds from the Fixed Rate Notes and Floating Rate Notes (collectively, the “Escrow Account”). The Escrow Account will be controlled by, and pledged on a
first-ranking basis in favor of, the Trustee (as defined herein), on behalf of the holders of the Notes, pursuant to the escrow agreement (the “Escrow Agreement”). The release of the
escrow proceeds (the “Escrow Release”) will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions as set out in the Escrow Agreement, including completion of the Acquisition. If the
conditions to Escrow Release are not satisfied on or prior to December 31, 2017 (the “Escrow Longstop Date”), then all of the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption.
The special mandatory redemption price will be a price equal to 100% of the aggregate initial issue price of the Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest from the relevant issue date of
the Notes to the date of special mandatory redemption. See “Description of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption”.

Unless otherwise indicated, the financial information presented in this offering memorandum is the
historical consolidated financial information of Empark and its subsidiaries (the “Group”). The
consolidated financial statements of the Group are prepared on the basis of a calendar year, ending
on December 31 of each year.

This offering memorandum contains:

-    the consolidated financial statements of the Group as of and for the six months ended June 30,
2017, which have been prepared in accordance with IAS 34 (with comparative data for the six
months ended June 30, 2016);

-    the consolidated financial statements of the Group as of and for the year ended December 31,
2016, which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS and audited by Ernst & Young, S.L.,
as set forth in their auditor’s report included elsewhere herein (with comparative data for the
year ended December 31, 2015); and

-    the consolidated financial statements of the Group as of and for the year ended December 31,
2015, which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS and audited by Ernst & Young, S.L.,
as set forth in their auditor’s report included elsewhere herein (with comparative data for the
year ended December 31, 2014).

The financial information presented herein as of and for the twelve months ended June 30, 2017 is
derived from the Group’s consolidated financial statements as of and for the six months ended
June 30, 2017 and the Group’s consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended
December 31, 2016 (in each case included elsewhere herein) by adding together the financial
information for the year ended December 31, 2016 and the financial information for the six months
ended June 30, 2017 and then subtracting the financial information for the six months ended June
30, 2016.

**Pro Forma Financial Information**
This offering memorandum includes unaudited consolidated pro forma financial data which has been
adjusted to reflect certain effects of the Transactions on the financial position and net financial

consolidated pro forma financial data has been prepared for illustrative purposes only and does not
purport to represent what the actual consolidated financial position or net financial expenses of the

calculation of net financial position and (ii) on July 1, 2016 for the purposes of the calculation of net
financial expenses, nor do they purport to project the Group’s consolidated financial position and net
financial expenses at any future date. The unaudited pro forma adjustments and the unaudited
_pro forma financial data set out in this offering memorandum are not accounting measures within the_
scope of IFRS and are based on available information and certain assumptions and estimates that
we believe are reasonable and may differ materially from the actual adjusted amounts. The primary,
unaudited pro forma financial measures that are used in this offering memorandum include pro forma
cash and other equivalent liquid assets, pro forma gross debt, pro forma net debt, pro forma net
recourse debt, pro forma cash interest expense and pro forma Adjusted EBITDA. See “Summary—
_Summary Financial, Operating and Other Information—Summary Pro Forma Financial Information”._

**Non-IFRS Measures**
The financial information included in this offering memorandum includes certain financial measures
which are not accounting measures within the scope of IFRS, and may not be permitted to appear on


-----

the face of primary financial statements or footnotes thereto and may not be permitted to be included
in filings under the U.S. Securities Act. The following are the primary non-IFRS financial measures
that are used in this offering memorandum:

-    Adjusted Revenue, which we define as net turnover plus other operating income less other
non-recurrent revenue less other “one off” or non-recurring gains and losses (including gains
and losses realized from the sale of parking spaces to local residents and gains and losses
realized on the sale of parking facilities);

-    EBITDA, which we define as consolidated operating results excluding amortization of fixed
assets and provisions and losses through unrecoverable receivables;

-    Adjusted EBITDA for the Group, which we define as EBITDA adjusted for (i) non-recurring
headquarter operating expenses (including redundancy payments and other related personnel
costs), (ii) non-recurring business unit expenses, and (iii) other “one off” or non-recurring gains
and losses (including gains and losses realized from the sale of parking spaces to local
residents and gains and losses realized on the sale and acquisition of parking facilities and
equity stakes in new subsidiaries);

-    Adjusted EBITDA by business line, which we define as EBITDA for the relevant business line
_adjusted for (i) reallocation of overhead costs and non-recurring headquarter operating_
expenses, (ii) non-recurring business unit expenses (including redundancy payments and other
related personnel costs) and (iii) other “one-off” or non-recurring gains and losses (including
gains and losses realized from the sale of parking spaces to local residents and gains and
losses realized on the sale and acquisition of parking facilities);

-    EBITDA Margin, which we define as EBITDA divided by the sum of net turnover and other
operating income;

-    Adjusted EBITDA Margin, which we define as Adjusted EBITDA divided by Adjusted Revenue;

-    Free Cash Flow, which we define as Adjusted EBITDA less maintenance capital expenditure,
changes in working capital, cash taxes and other non-cash items. Other non-cash items
comprise dividends received, receipts/payments through taxation of profits, payments (IFRIC
12), and other receipts/payments;

-    Free Cash Flow Conversion, which we define as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA;

-    Weighted Average Remaining Duration of our concessions, which we define as the average
period of time remaining on our concessions and contracts, weighted by the contribution each
concession has made to our Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2016;

-    Gross debt, which we define as debt from our bank loans and other borrowings, including
accrued interest and excluding unamortized debt issue costs;

-    Net debt, which we define as Gross debt less Cash and other equivalent liquid assets;

-    Recourse cash and other equivalent liquid assets, which we define as Cash and other
equivalent liquid assets held by all members of the Group excluding the Non-Recourse Entities;

-    Non-recourse cash and other equivalent liquid assets, which we define as Cash and other
equivalent liquid assets held by the Non-Recourse Entities;

-    Gross recourse debt, which we define as Gross debt excluding debt of the Non-Recourse
Entities;

-    Gross non-recourse debt, which we define as debt of the Non-Recourse Entities, including
accrued interest and excluding unamortized debt issue costs;

-    Net recourse debt, which we define as Gross recourse debt less Recourse cash and other
equivalent liquid assets; and

-    Net non-recourse debt, which we define as Gross non-recourse debt less Non-recourse cash
and other equivalent liquid assets.


-----

See “Summary—Summary Financial, Operating and Other Information” and “Management’s
_Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operation” for further information_
about and the calculation of these non-IFRS financial measures.

You should exercise caution in comparing any of the above non-IFRS financial measures as reported
by us to corresponding measures of other companies. The EBITDA measures presented in this
offering memorandum differ from the definition of “Consolidated EBITDA” set forth under the caption
“Description of Notes—Certain Definitions”. By eliminating potential differences between periods or
companies caused by factors such as depreciation and amortization methods, financing and capital
structures and taxation positions or regimes, we believe these non-IFRS financial measures can
provide a useful additional basis for comparing the current performance of the underlying operations
being evaluated. For these reasons, we believe these non-IFRS financial measures and similar
measures are regularly used by the investment community as a means of comparing companies in
our industry.

Our management also uses the non-IFRS financial measures described above to assess our
operating and financial performance and to make decisions about allocating resources in our
business. For example, management monitors the Weighted Average Remaining Duration for our
concessions in order to evaluate future cash flow variability and any associated risk.

None of the non-IFRS financial measures presented herein are a measurement of performance under
IFRS and they should not be considered in isolation or construed as a substitute for (a) operating
profit or profit for the period (as determined in accordance with IFRS) as a measure of our operating
performance, (b) cash flow from operating, investment and financing activities as a measure of our
ability to meet our cash needs or (c) any other measures of performance or liquidity.

The non-IFRS financial measures presented herein have limitations as analytical tools, including the
following:

-    they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital expenditures,
contractual commitments or working capital;

-    they do not reflect the significant interest expense or the cash requirements necessary to
service interest or principal payments on our debts;

-    although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated
and amortized will often need to be replaced in the future, and the non-IFRS financial
measures do not reflect any cash requirements that would be required for such replacements;

-    some of the exceptional items that we eliminate in calculating the relevant non-IFRS financial
measures reflect cash payments that were made, or will in the future be made;

-    other companies in our industry may calculate the non-IFRS financial measures presented
herein differently than we do, which limits their usefulness as a comparative measure; and

-    they remove the results of impairments and disposals of fixed assets which may also occur in
future periods.

Certain amounts and percentages included in this offering memorandum have been rounded.
Accordingly, in certain instances, the sum of the numbers in a column of a table may not exactly
equal the total figure for that column.

The financial information included in this offering memorandum is not intended to comply with the
applicable accounting requirements of the U.S. Securities Act and the related rules and regulations of
the SEC which would apply if the Notes were being registered with the SEC.

**Overview**
We are one of the leading concessionaires and operators of parking infrastructure in the Iberian
Peninsula, as measured by number of parking spaces and revenues. We mainly operate
underground car parks (“off-street”), as well as some parking areas on city streets (“on-street”) under
concessions and surface rights agreements from public authorities. As of June 30, 2017, our portfolio
comprised 432 contracts in 189 municipalities and other contracts with customers such as AENA and
ANA, the respective Spanish and Portuguese public airport operators, under which we manage over
522,000 parking spaces in Spain, Portugal, the United Kingdom, Andorra, France and Turkey. For the
twelve months ended June 30, 2017, our net turnover was €206.0 million, our Adjusted Revenue was
€205.7 million and our Adjusted EBITDA was €73.2 million. Our operations in Spain and Portugal,
respectively, represented 67.6% and 20.6% of our net turnover, 67.6% and 20.6% of our Adjusted
Revenue, 68.8% and 28.8% of our gross profits, 68.4% and 29.8% of our Adjusted EBITDA and
75.9% and 11.8% of our parking spaces for the twelve months ended June 30, 2017.

We have served the Iberian market since the late 1960s. We believe this has given us a “first mover”
advantage, whereby we have continually secured long-term concessions and built a portfolio of prime
parking locations in Spain and Portugal, including in city centers, airports and other high density
traffic areas, such as hospitals and business districts. Due to a variety of physical, regulatory and
other constraints such as cost of space, we believe that there is limited opportunity to develop
alternative parking options in many of these prime areas, allowing us to benefit from captive demand
with limited competition.

We generate revenues under three business lines:

-    Off-street concessions. Our off-street concession business primarily comprises long-term
concessions, with contract lengths generally ranging from 20 years to 50 years, granted by
municipalities to develop and operate underground or multi-story parking facilities, and
represented 50.5% of our Adjusted Revenue, 85.8% of our Adjusted EBITDA and 60.5% of our
Adjusted EBITDA Margin for the twelve months ended June 30, 2017. Under these contracts,
we are generally required to invest in the construction of a new parking facility (a “green field”
concession) or make an upfront payment to the municipality for an existing parking facility (a
“brown field” concession). We operate each parking facility on a long-term basis and generate
our fees based on tariffs charged to car park users, as set out in the relevant concession or
surface rights agreement, which typically increase each year in line with inflation. We generally
retain all fees generated from operating the relevant parking facility and are responsible for all
expenses relating to operating and maintaining the parking facility during the term of the
concession. With respect to “brown field” concessions, we may pay an annual concession fee
to the municipality, an upfront fee or a combination of both. In addition, we sell a limited
number of parking spaces to local residents as an ancillary activity in connection with the
development of some parking facilities. As of June 30, 2017, we had 298 off-street concession
contracts (including 84 resident contracts) with 84 municipalities under which we manage
approximately 124,350 parking spaces. The Weighted Average Remaining Duration of our offstreet concessions was approximately 25 years as of June 30, 2017.

-    On-street concessions. Our on-street concession business comprises concessions, with
contract lengths generally ranging from five to 20 years, granted by municipalities to manage
meter-controlled on-street parking, and represented 33.5% of our Adjusted Revenue, 14.2% of


-----

our Adjusted EBITDA and 15.1% of our Adjusted EBITDA Margin in the twelve months ended
June 30, 2017. For these types of contracts, we typically receive fixed fees that are inflationindexed and which cover the yearly amortized amount of our initial investment and operating
costs and reasonable rate of return. In a number of concessions, the contract also includes a
variable incentive element (which may be based on a percentage of the collected meter
receipts, the number of parking spaces or certain other indicators) to align the concessionaire’s
objectives with optimizing revenue collection. As of June 30, 2017, we had 123 on-street
concession contracts (including nine tow-away contracts) with 104 municipalities under which
we manage approximately 267,000 parking spaces. The Weighted Average Remaining
Duration of our on-street concessions was approximately six years as of June 30, 2017.

-    Off-street contract management. Our off-street contract management business involves
contracts to manage parking facilities on behalf of public authorities, primarily airports, as well
as a limited number of private entities. Our off-street contract management business
represented 16.0% of our Adjusted Revenue and did not contribute to our Adjusted EBITDA in
a meaningful way in the twelve months ended June 30, 2017. As of June 30, 2017, we had 11
off-street management contracts. Under these contracts, we operate and manage parking
facilities with approximately 132,000 parking spaces on behalf of third parties in exchange for a
fixed fee. Although it is a relatively small part of our overall business, our off-street contract
management business line allows us to leverage our expertise in managing car parks to
improve our cash flow with minimal capital costs and reduced overhead costs due to our
centralized platform, improve our access to municipalities and build local market knowledge.

**Strengths**
We believe that we have several competitive advantages in the car park sector in Iberia, including our
long-term contract revenues, diversified business profile, assets with low demand risk and market
leadership. As a result of these strengths, together with the stable regulatory environment and
favorable industry dynamics, our business benefits from a high level of stability and recurring cash
flows.

**_Uniquely positioned for growth on the back of Iberia’s favorable macroeconomic trends_**
The macroeconomic environment in Spain and Portugal, our largest geographic markets in terms of
revenues, has gradually improved since 2013 and is expected to continue to improve in the
foreseeable future. The on-going macroeconomic recovery in Spain and Portugal is mainly driven by
GDP growth and a decrease in unemployment rates, with the unemployment rate in Spain expected
to be 4.5% lower in the next five years, which are the main macroeconomic factors impacting
disposable income, and therefore, retail, business traffic, petrol, and overall consumption. The car
park industry has been growing in Iberia mainly driven by this macroeconomic recovery as well as a
result of the increase in urbanization and an increase in the number of cars. The profitability of the
sector is generally improving, supported by scale efficiencies, the implementation of cost savings
programs and the utilization of innovative industry technology, among other factors. We believe that
we are well positioned to benefit from the continued improvement in the economic environment in
Iberia resulting in organic growth opportunities for us. The economic recovery in Iberia may also lead
to consolidation opportunities that provide room for further non-organic growth. We believe that
improvements in our cost savings, business activity and revenues in connection with such economic
improvement, together with our various cost efficiency initiatives, will have a positive effect on our
EBITDA.

**_Leading car park concessionaire in Iberia benefitting from scale and high barriers to_**
**_market entry_**
We are one of the leading car park concessionaires in the Iberian parking infrastructure concessions
market both by revenue and number of parking spaces. As of June 30, 2017, we managed 397,012
parking spaces in Spain, 61,897 in Portugal, 54,672 in the United Kingdom, 4,575 in Turkey, 3,258 in
France and 1,425 in Andorra. We had over 20.5 million car parking transactions in the twelve months
ended June 30, 2017, based on the number of payments made across all our car parks. In 2016, we
had a market share of approximately 16% based on revenues. Our size and growth have allowed us
to achieve significant economies of scale, and the scope of our operations, combined with the various
cost management measures we have implemented, have allowed us to maintain our Adjusted
EBITDA levels. For example, our centralized system controls and manages a substantial majority of
our off-street concessions business parking facilities from a remote location, which has allowed us to
reduce headcount and personnel costs without impacting our service quality and customer
satisfaction levels. Such efficiencies have led to significant savings in operating expenses as we
reduced the number of operators per car park by more than half. In addition, our mobile maintenance
personnel is responsible for the maintenance of several car parks within a defined geographic area,
which reduces personnel expenses and standby time. This has allowed us to reallocate personnel to
perform certain functions previously outsourced, thereby reducing our reliance on third-party service
providers. Our economies of scale enable us to be a consolidation platform for smaller Iberian
parking operations, and allow us to undertake valuable new concessions and acquisitions of smaller
players. For example, when we acquired Car Parking, S.L.U. in 2014, EMSA - Empreendimentos e
Exploração de Estacionamentos S.A. (“EMSA”) in 2015 and SIENT - Sistemas de Engenharia de
Transito, S.A. (“Sient”) in 2016, we integrated each company into our centralized system to reduce
the number of staff on site, ensured maintenance works were performed by dedicated local teams
and arranged for management services relating to human resources, tax or accounting, to be
conducted by centralized management teams. In addition, through our experienced management
team and our long-standing reputation in the industry, we have been able to develop and maintain
important relationships with the various municipalities with which we do business, thereby reducing
our dependence on any single local authority or region.


-----

We believe the upfront cost and difficulty in obtaining planning permission to build new high density
car parks in city centers, together with the favorable regulatory regime that applies to concession
agreements in Spain and Portugal as discussed under “—Stable regulatory environment with
_downside protection” below, as well as the scale required to operate car parks efficiently present_
significant barriers to entry in the car park industry. The stringent regulatory framework governing
parking concessions in Iberia reduces the risk of new competitors entering the market. For example,
due to the terms and lengths of concession contracts, competitors can be locked-out of the off-street
concessions business for long periods of time. In addition, our size provides us with the scale
required to operate a car park portfolio efficiently. For example, our scale enables us to share
resources among our car parks including maintenance and supervisory staff, as well as management
resources in respect of accounting, marketing, human resources, insurance and tax matters. The
number of our locations also gives us a commercial advantage as we are able to anticipate customer
needs across multiple locations. In addition, the high initial investment required to produce efficient IT
resources is beyond the reach of smaller competitors. Between 2014 and June 30, 2017, we invested
approximately €3.9 million in IT resources. Unlike smaller operators, we can price into our bids the
efficiencies that we can generate through our portfolio, and thus offer more attractive terms to
municipalities. Also, as there is a lack of available land in the major city centers of Iberia, there are
limited opportunities to construct new car parks, and our scale provides us with numerous
consolidation and expansion opportunities, which many smaller competitors are unable to take
advantage of.

**_High degree of diversification_**

Our business benefits from a portfolio which is highly diversified in terms of the following: number of
contracts, number of municipality clients and types of parking services we deliver. We are also diversified
through our three business lines, each of which has different risk profiles and capital requirements, but with
similar operational and managerial requirements. As of June 30, 2017, we had 432 contracts including
298 off-street concession contracts (including 84 resident contracts), 123 on-street concession contracts
(including nine tow-away contracts) and 11 off-street management contracts with customers such as
AENA, ANA, Gatwick Airport Limited (“Gatwick”) and Edinburgh Airport Limited (“Edinburgh”). Our off-street
and on-street concession contracts were granted in 189 municipalities in Iberia. Our off-street concession
business line is further diversified in terms of location, municipality, end user and type of contract (business
district, hospitals, shopping areas and tourism). We believe our limited reliance on any single contract is a
significant factor in diversifying our source of revenues and therefore reduces our cash flow volatility. While
our 10 largest off-street car parks represented approximately 12.3% of our total gross profit for the twelve
months ended June 30, 2017, our largest car park represented less than 2% of our total gross profit during
the same period. We believe our diversified business portfolio differentiates us from other infrastructure
companies, who typically rely on a smaller number of larger contracts or concessions, with a greater
concentration of risk.

**_Strategically located assets with attractive concessions and limited demand risk_**

We believe that our infrastructure portfolio is well invested. Our on-street concession and off-street contract
management businesses have low demand risk because we are generally paid a fixed fee for the services
we provide, regardless of occupancy of the car park. Although our off-street concession business is subject
to demand risk and fluctuations in volumes, we believe the prime locations of our concessions will continue
attracting car park users and ensuring stable utilization levels given our car parks are located in high traffic
areas at or within close proximity to city centers. Our business was created as a result of the acquisition of
the two historical leaders in the parking concessions market in Spain and Portugal, each with prime
concessions already in place. As a result, we were able to construct car parks in strategic locations,
including Playa de la Concha in San Sebastián, Plaza Mayor in Madrid and Camões in Lisbon, and take
advantage of the existing concessions which were located within close proximity to city centers and in high
traffic areas. Therefore, we believe that we enjoy a prime position in the relevant local area with respect to
a significant proportion of our parking facilities. Moreover, the high density of city centers together with
planning regulations make the approval process for “green field” concessions difficult, effectively limiting
the supply of parking spaces in a given area. Additionally, many of our concessions in strategic locations
have a long remaining life, such as Camões, Lisbon (34 years, 340 car spaces), Playa de la Concha, San
Sebastián (41 years, 1,274 car spaces), Joan de Borbó, Barcelona (22 years, 638 car spaces) and
Restauradores, Lisbon (30 years, 545 car spaces). The prime positions of our car parks and the difficulty in
building new car parks helps to reduce the demand risk in our off-street concession business.


-----

**_Stable regulatory environment with downside protection_**
The regulatory framework governing off-street and on-street parking concessions in Spain and
Portugal affords certain protections to the concessionaire. We and other car park concessionaires
that operate in Iberia have historically benefitted from a “rebalancing” clause under the relevant
concession legislation in Spain and Portugal, which may also apply to Portuguese public surface
rights agreements. Under certain circumstances, a change in the balance of the economic terms and
conditions of the concession that is adverse to the concessionaire will trigger a right of the
concessionaire to seek compensation or a “rebalancing” mechanism, which typically results in either
an extension of the concession period, an increase in tariffs payable by users, or sometimes an
increase in the number of parking spaces managed by the concessionaire, depending on the
circumstances. This regulatory environment has proven to be stable and predictable since the
implementation of the concession system more than 50 years ago and in the past, we have been
successful in relying on such protective legislation to seek additional compensation. Additionally, the
municipalities granting concessions have an interest in the success of public car parks since they are
a source of income for the municipality and the operation of car parks satisfies a public need.

**_Highly stable business with limited maintenance capital expenditure requirements_**
For the twelve months ended June 30, 2017, 85.8% of our Adjusted EBITDA was generated by our
off-street concessions business, which had a Weighted Average Remaining Duration of approximately
25 years. Since 2014, we have achieved a Replacement Rate of approximately 235%. Our off-street
concessions business also benefits from regulated tariffs linked to inflation. Accordingly, we benefit
from a high level of recurring business and long-term visibility of cash flows, and we believe the longterm nature of our portfolio is matched by few other infrastructure companies in Spain and Portugal.
The most significant contracts in the off-street portfolio are public concession agreements, with none
or limited rent payments, which is not the case of a typical lease contract more common in other
European countries.

We have achieved a Replacement Rate of approximately 113% since 2014 with respect to our onstreet concessions business. During the same period, we achieved a Renewal Rate of approximately
71% in respect of on-street car parks we manage. In addition, we also won a number of our
competitors’ contracts and in some instances, we have successfully renewed our on-street
concessions business despite our competitors submitting more competitively priced bids than us. We
believe this is due to our superior technical competence, including the implementation of state of the
art revenue collection technology, and our wealth of industry experience.

Despite the decrease in demand and volumes within our parking facilities that we experienced during
the prior economic downturn, we were able to mitigate some of the effects through inflation-indexed
price tariffs under the majority of our off-street and on-street concessions business and off-street
contract management agreements, as well as growth in our concession portfolio and our
implementation of cost management measures. The stability of our business and the resilience of our
Adjusted EBITDA during the economic downturn are illustrated in the chart below.

Our business model shares all the key features of infrastructure companies, such as long-term cash
flow visibility, resilient revenue generation, long-term concessions and a favorable and stable
regulatory environment with certain protections for the concessionaire in case of regulatory or
administrative change. However, unlike some other infrastructure companies (including those
operating toll roads), our car parks, once operational, require relatively low levels of maintenance


-----

capital expenditure. Our limited maintenance capital expenditures are a result of our scale and
preventive maintenance measures and low operating intensity. On average, between 2014 and 2016,
our annual total maintenance capital expenditure totaled €2.3 million, representing 1.2% of our
Adjusted Revenue during the same period and mainly relating to the requirements of our car park
contracts, including recurring maintenance works and repairs on our car park facilities to ensure that
they remain fully operational and compliant. As a result, we believe we are well positioned to benefit
from returns on these investments without the need to make significant maintenance capital
expenditures with respect to these facilities.

We benefit from attractive working capital dynamics with low levels of credit risk with respect to our
off-street concession business, since such revenues are collected from users when they exit the car
park. Our current business does not require significant investment in working capital. For example,
our off-street concessions business line generates negative working capital because our revenues
are generally collected when earned and our costs are paid according to standard payment terms as
agreed in each of our contracts. However, our on-street and contract management businesses have
higher working capital requirements as they are more dependent on the payment terms from
contracts with public bodies. In addition, our credit risk with respect to our on-street concessions
business is primarily with the municipalities rather than private third parties. As a result of our low
maintenance capital expenditures and working capital requirements, we have achieved significant
Free Cash Flow Conversion ratios of 87.1% and 91.3% for the year ended December 31, 2016 and
the twelve months ended June 30, 2017, respectively.

Any larger capital expenditures are primarily related to the expansion of our business, including new
acquisitions and grants of new contracts and concessions. We are constantly securing new contracts
and concessions as existing contracts and concessions expire. These are based on our analysis of
investment opportunities and are typically not linked to prior commitments. Capital expenditures
linked to the expansion of the business depend upon specific requirements from newly awarded
contracts. For example, in 2016 our capital expenditures included the impact of the acquisition of the
remaining 50% stake in each of Alhóndiga, Aparcamientos de Bilbao, EMSA and Sient (€9.6 million);
the new on-street contract in Porto, Portugal (€9.7 million) and off-street concessions business capital
expenditures related to Parque Brasilia and Infanto Santo in Portugal, and Hospital Ramón y Cajal, El
Ejido and Las Terrazas de Marbella in Spain (approximately €11.1 million). Additional capital
expenditures may be required in connection with the renewal of on-street contracts nearing their
maturity date. Our limited maintenance capital expenditure requirements and high Free Cash Flow
Conversion ratios are illustrated by the charts below.

**_Experienced management team with strong, supportive shareholders_**
Our senior management team has significant experience and understanding of the car park sector
and has an average of 14 years of experience in the industry and 12 years of experience with the
Company. Our senior management team has consistently over performed on budget targets, through
the successful integration of our businesses and significant cost savings achievements. This over
performance can also be attributed to the senior management team’s ability to anticipate and
embrace new trends and technology in the car park sector, which has enabled us to be a pioneer in
the deployment of efficient improvement programs and user friendly applications, such as electronic
payment devices, license plate recognition systems and mobile applications.

In addition, our senior management team maintains strong and long-standing local relationships with
the relevant regulatory authorities in the jurisdictions in which we operate.

We also expect to derive further benefit from the experience and financial support of the Macquarie
Group following the completion of the Acquisition. The Macquarie Group, through its MIRA division, is
the world’s largest infrastructure manager by assets under management, according to IPE Real
Estate, and a global leader in the creation and management of specialist funds which focus on
infrastructure, real estate and adjacent sectors. As of March 31, 2017, MIRA has more than
€110 billion of assets under management. MIRA’s European investment portfolio includes businesses
located in Austria, Belgium, the Czech Republic, France, Germany, Italy, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia,
Spain, Sweden and the United Kingdom.


-----

**Strategy**
Our key strategies are the following:

**_Maintain focus on growing revenue and improving EBITDA_**
We will continue to implement measures designed to increase our revenues and thus enhance our
EBITDA and cash flows. Generally, under our concession agreements, we are subject to limitations
with respect to the maximum tariff that we can charge users of our parking facilities. As a result, we
have the flexibility to structure our pricing policy as we deem fit so long as we do not exceed the
maximum tariffs set forth in the concession agreement. Our pricing policy varies on a case by case
basis, and we may use any or all of the following pricing mechanics in order to maximize demand
and volumes: (i) season tickets, whereby we can offer a range of different products to fit our
customers’ specific needs (for example, offering specific time slots on specific days or for specific
periods of time), which can help to increase volumes during those times of the day when rotation is
less intensive, as well as have a positive impact on our working capital as a result of receiving
payments in advance, (ii) different tariff structures, whereby tariffs will differ, for example, based on
the time of day or the day of the week, and (iii) long-dated sales, whereby we can expand our product
and service offering by developing special offers and promotions designed in partnership with third
parties, such as travel agencies in connection with holiday packages or special events.

We also seek to increase revenue and volumes within our off-street concessions business parking
facilities through increased deployment of car park signage and other forms of advertising in city
centers and other high traffic areas in which our car parks are located. In addition, we anticipate that
revenues from our large parking facilities opened in the past three years will increase over the
coming years as they are currently in the “ramp up” phase. Within our on-street concession business,
we seek to continue improving our revenue collection through the implementation of best practices,
such as our integrated platform for payment (Telpark) and visual car enforcement in order to increase
revenues collected for the relevant municipality, which will thereby increase the level of variable
incentive compensation we receive under such concession. Moreover, we intend to continue to
implement technological improvements to achieve greater efficiency, which will allow us to more
efficiently manage the parking areas covered by our on-street concessions business and increase the
number of parking spaces covered per employee. For example, we plan on increasing the number of
car parks, both from our existing portfolio and new acquisitions that will be connected to our
centralized control room in order to reduce fixed costs. Upon completion of the Acquisition, we aim to
realize further net cost savings of approximately €2.3 million consisting of overhead cost savings of
approximately €3.3 million relating to the departure of top management, partially offset by €1.0 million
in additional costs we expect to incur for the appointment of a new chief executive officer and new
chief financial officer. For further information, see “Management—Empark—Transitional Services
_Agreements”._

**_Maintain our disciplined and high operational efficiency_**
We will continue to focus on managing our business in a cost-efficient manner by using the latest
industry technologies and improving customer service. We will also continue to work with car
manufacturers to implement new technology systems. In the past, we have invested in and installed
several user-friendly IT applications to enhance the customer experience at our car parks including
electronic payment devices such as Via Verde, license plate recognition systems and mobile
applications, such as Telpark, for both off-street and on-street car parking. We plan to continue to
improve and extend the application of our cost-effective practices, such as monthly contract-bycontract cost base reviews, the centralization of the daily management of our off-street concessions
business car parks from a remote location, our energy efficiency programs and our on-street
efficiency programs. Furthermore we will continue to maintain our well invested assets in order to
keep our required level of maintenance capital expenditure low, and we plan to eliminate certain
overhead costs not required for continued operations.

**_Preserve and selectively expand our high quality portfolio of long-term concessions_**
We have a diversified portfolio of concessions and contracts in prime locations and will strive to
maintain and renew these concessions and contracts in order to maintain our stable cash flow
generation. We believe our infrastructure is well-invested. The total expansionary capital expenditure
for the period from 2014 to 2016 was €57.5 million. As a result, we intend to focus our efforts on


-----

renewing our portfolio of existing concessions and contracts by maintaining our well invested assets
in anticipation of future renewal capital expenditure requirements and organically expanding our
operations by capturing new concessions and contracts. For example, due to our market leading
position, scale and expertise, we believe that we are well positioned to continue to grow our
diversified portfolio by renewing our existing contracts and concessions and capturing new contracts
and concessions from both existing customers seeking to award new concessions and from other
organizations looking to outsource the management of their parking facilities. For example, in line
with our historical strategy, we may acquire high quality smaller car parks in prime locations and to
incorporate them into our centralized control room, which will increase our portfolio of assets that
benefit from our mobile maintenance personnel. Due to our scale, long-standing experience in this
industry and established relationships with municipalities, we are able to achieve significant synergies
that also allow us to offer more competitive terms than those offered by our competitors. We believe
our position as one of the leading concessionaires of off-street concessions and on-street
concessions parking in Iberia, combined with our long-standing relationships with a diverse number of
local authorities and favorable industry dynamics, including high barriers to entry, will assist us in
continuing to implement this strategy.

**_Strategic focus on off-street concessions business in Iberia_**
We will continue to focus on managing our core business segments within Iberia, principally the offstreet segment. We may opportunistically consider dispositions of non-core operations and
geographies, in order to enhance the risk profile of investment capital expenditures and improve
profitability. In addition, as part of our long-term strategy, we may consider strategic options regarding
the on-street concession business line, off-street contract management and business outside of Iberia
in order to fully focus on our off-street concession business, which has a higher EBITDA Margin.

**History and Ownership**
We commenced our operations in Iberia under the name Cintra Parking (the name of Empark prior to
its acquisition of Emparque) in Spain in the 1960s. Emparque commenced operations in Portugal in
the 1970s.

Over the last five decades, our business has expanded through a combination of organic growth and
a series of mergers and acquisitions. The growth culminated in July 2009, when the Group was
created following a series of transactions whereby Cintra Parking acquired and merged with
Emparque. Since then, we have expanded our operations with a sustained focus on Iberia.

We are now in the process of being acquired by the Sponsor. We expect this acquisition to be
completed on the Completion Date. See “The Transactions”.

**Principal Shareholder**

Upon completion of the Acquisition on the Completion Date, the Group, will be indirectly owned by the
Sponsor which is managed by MIRAEL, a member of the Macquarie Group. The Macquarie Group,
through its MIRA division, is the world’s largest infrastructure manager by assets under management,
according to IPE Real Estate, and a global leader in the creation and management of specialist funds
which focus on infrastructure, real estate and adjacent sectors. As of March 31, 2017, MIRA has more than
€110 billion of assets under management. MIRA’s European investment portfolio includes businesses
located in Austria, Belgium, the Czech Republic, France, Germany, Italy, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Spain,
Sweden and the United Kingdom. MIRA takes a partnership approach, working with local management
teams and bringing specialist strategic, commercial, operational and financial expertise through its global
team of operations and industry experts. Globally, MIRA actively manages 46 funds and mandates across
infrastructure, real estate, agriculture and energy, which have been invested in over 200 infrastructure
businesses. In Europe, MIRA has to date raised and invested through five dedicated European
infrastructure funds with commitments totalling over €14 billion.

**The Transactions**

**_The Acquisition_**
On July 28, 2017, Bidco, an entity formed by the Sponsor for purposes of facilitating the Acquisition,
entered into a sale and purchase agreement (the “Acquisition Agreement”) with the Sellers to acquire
all the issued and outstanding share capital of the Target from the Sellers. The cash consideration for
the Acquisition, together with the Debt Repayment and estimated transaction fees and expenses, is
expected to be in aggregate €942.5 million. Completion of the Acquisition is expected to occur in
December 2017. If the actions to be undertaken at the scheduled date of consummation of the
transaction are not conducted (and not remedied within the relevant time periods provided therefore),
the Acquisition Agreement may be terminated by the non-breaching party.

**_The Financing and Completion Date Transactions_**
The financing in connection with the Acquisition consists of (i) an indirect cash contribution by the
Sponsor in the amount of €467.5 million, and (ii) the gross proceeds from the issuance of the Notes
in the amount of €475.0 million (assuming the Notes are issued at par), which together will be used to
finance (i) the payment of cash consideration for the Acquisition to the Sellers in the amount of
€486.0 million, (ii) the Debt Repayment at the Target Group in the amount of €424.0 million, and (iii)
€32.5 million in related fees and expenses, including fees and expenses incurred in connection with
the Offering. See “The Transactions—The Financing and Completion Date Transactions” and “Use of
_Proceeds”._

_Release of proceeds from escrow_
Pending the completion of the Acquisition, the gross proceeds of the Offering will be deposited into
the Escrow Account in the name of the Issuer but controlled by, and pledged on a first-ranking basis
in favor of, the Trustee, on behalf of the holders of the Notes, pursuant to the Escrow Agreement. The
release of the escrow proceeds will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including the
completion of the Acquisition. See “Description of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory
_Redemption”. If the Acquisition is not completed on or prior to the Escrow Longstop Date, or upon the_
occurrence of certain other events, then all of the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory
redemption. The special mandatory redemption price will be equal to 100% of the initial issue price of
the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, from the Issue Date up to,
but not including, the payment date of such special mandatory redemption. See “Description of
_Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption”._

_Use of Proceeds_
We estimate that the gross proceeds from the Offering will be €475.0 million. Upon release from
escrow, the net proceeds from the Offering will be on lent by the Issuer to Bidco by (i) the Debt
Repayment Proceeds Loan to finance the Debt Repayment; and (ii) the Acquisition and Fees
Proceeds Loan to finance a portion of the cash purchase price of the Acquisition and to pay related
fees and expenses.

**Recent Developments**

**_Trading update_**
Based on preliminary management accounts for July and August 2017, we estimate that our Adjusted
EBITDA experienced growth in the range of 4% and 5% compared to the same period in 2016. This
growth is in line with the trend observed in the six months ended June 30, 2017. During the same
period our off-street like-for-like revenues experienced growth in the range of 4% and 5% compared
to the same period in 2016.

Since September 2013, we have experienced consistent, positive growth in our off-street like-for-like
revenues with the volume of transactions returning to the levels that existed prior to the economic
downturn in Iberia. Accordingly, we believe that we are well positioned to continue to benefit from a
sustained economic recovery in the Iberian Peninsula.

We use like-for-like revenues to provide a comparison between all net turnover and other operating
income generated under our off-street concession business line during a specified month in the
current year and all net turnover and other operating income generated under our off-street
concession business line during the same month for the prior year, as adjusted to eliminate any new
concessions and any concessions that expired or were terminated during the periods being
compared. Accordingly, if an off-street concession was being managed in 2016, but is no longer
managed in 2017, the net turnover and other operating income generated under that concession in
2016 is not included for purposes of this comparison.

preliminary estimates above, and such variations could be material. See “Forward-Looking
_Statements” and “Risk Factors” for a more complete discussion of certain of the factors that could_
affect our future performance and results of operations.

(16) Bidco will enter into the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement on or prior to the Issue Date. The Revolving Credit Facility will
have a total commitment of €75 million and will mature six years after the Completion Date or if earlier, six months prior to
the maturity date of the Notes. Borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility will be available to fund, among other things,
the Group’s general corporate and working capital purposes (including acquisitions (excluding the Acquisition and its related
costs, fees and expenses), capital expenditure and investments) and may be drawn in euros. The Revolving Credit Facility
will be guaranteed by all of the Parent Guarantor’s subsidiaries that guarantee the Notes (including the Issuer). The property
and assets that secure the Notes and the Guarantees also secure the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement as well as certain
priority hedging obligations on an equal and ratable basis. Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, the holders of the
Notes will receive proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral and certain distressed disposals only after the lenders
under the Revolving Credit Facility and counterparties to certain priority hedging obligations have been paid in full. See
“Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement”.

**Redemption for Taxation Reasons.. In the event of certain developments affecting taxation or**
certain other circumstances, the Issuer may redeem the Notes
in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of
100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid
interest, if any, and additional amounts, if any, to the date of
redemption. See “Description of Notes—Redemption for
_Changes in Taxes”._

**Change of Control** ........................... Upon the occurrence of a Change of Control (as defined
herein), the Issuer will be required to offer to repurchase all
outstanding Notes at a purchase price in cash equal to 101%
of the principal amount thereof on the date of purchase, plus
accrued and unpaid interest to the date of repurchase. See
“Description of Notes—Repurchase at the Option of Holders—
_Change of Control”._


-----

**Covenants ........................................ The Indenture, among other things, will restrict the ability of the**
Parent Guarantor and its restricted subsidiaries to:

                         - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue
certain preferred stock;

                         - create or incur certain liens;

                         - make certain payments, including dividends or other
distributions, with respect to the shares of the Parent
Guarantor;

                         - prepay or redeem subordinated debt or equity;

                         - make certain investments;

                         - create encumbrances or restrictions on the payment of
dividends or other distributions, loans or advances to
and on the transfer of assets to the Parent Guarantor or
its restricted subsidiaries;

                         - sell, lease or transfer certain assets including stock of
restricted subsidiaries;

                         - consolidate or merge with other entities;

                         - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders
of the Notes; and

                         - amend certain documents.

Each of these covenants is subject to significant exceptions
and qualifications. See “Description of Notes—Certain
_Covenants”._

**Additional Amounts ........................ All payments made by or on behalf of the Issuer or any of the**
Guarantors under or with respect to the Notes or any Note
Guarantee will be made free and clear of and without
withholding or deduction for, or on account of, any present or
future Taxes unless the withholding or deduction of such Taxes
is then required by law. If any deduction or withholding for, or
on account of, any such Taxes will at any time be required to
be made, the Issuer or the relevant Guarantor will, subject to
certain exceptions, pay the additional amounts necessary so
that the net amount received by the holders of the relevant
Notes after the deduction or withholding will equal the
respective amounts that would have been received in respect
of such payments in the absence of such withholding or
deduction. See “Description of Notes—Additional Amounts”.

**Denominations................................. The Notes will be issued in registered form and transferable in**
minimum denominations of €100,000 and integral multiples of
€1,000 in excess thereof.

**Transfer Restrictions** ....................... The Notes have not been and will not be registered under the
U.S. Securities Act or the securities laws of any other
jurisdiction. The Notes are subject to restrictions on
transferability and resale. Holders of the Notes will not have the
benefit of any exchange or registration rights. See “Notice to
_Investors”._

**No Prior Market................................ The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no**
market. Although the Initial Purchasers have informed the
Issuer that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are
not obligated to do so and may discontinue market-making at
any time without notice. Accordingly, there can be no

assurance that a liquid market for the Notes will develop or be
maintained.

by the Luxembourg Stock Exchange and for the Notes to be
listed on the Official List of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange
and admitted to trading on the Euro MTF market. There can be
no assurance that the Notes will be, or will remain, so listed
and admitted to trading on the Euro MTF market.

**Use of Proceeds .............................. We will use the gross proceeds of the Notes as set forth in**
“Use of Proceeds”.

Agreement, the Intercreditor Agreement and the Escrow

creating security interests over the Collateral will be governed

doubt, Articles 84 to 94-8 of the Luxembourg Act dated
