# Regulation

The following is a brief summary of the regulatory regimes of Spain and Portugal applicable to our
business.

**Spain**

**_General_**
Car parks in Spain may be developed either privately or through the public concessionary regime.
Car parks developed through the public concessionary regime are usually located on publicly owned
land and involve the exercise of public administrative powers (principally by municipalities). The legal
regime governing car parks developed through the public concessionary regime is more complex
than that for private car parks. This is the reason why this section is almost entirely devoted to car
parks developed through the public concessionary regime. The operation of public car parks, which is
usually granted to private parties under administrative concessions, is subject to the ongoing control
of the public authorities that grant the concessions.

Car parks that are privately developed are usually built on privately owned land and are subject to a
less complex regulatory regime than the regime applicable to car parks developed through the public
concessionary regime.

Law 40/2002 of November 14 regulates car park agreements and sets forth the duties of car park
operators and their liabilities for personal injury and property damage.

Under the relevant Spanish laws, the operator of a parking facility is liable for any damages to the
vehicle and its contents. The provider of parking services is liable for movable components,
accessories or objects when certain conditions are met, including that such movable components,
accessories or objects are expressly declared by the user, that the provider of parking services
expressly accepts their custody, and that the user complies with security measures.

**_Off-street Car Parks_**
Off-street car parks can be classified as follows:

a)    Ownership: The asset is owned by the company and is freely operated exclusively for its own
benefit. A parking contract with end users is ruled by Law 40/2002 on vehicle parking which
(since its amendment by means of Law 44/2006) sets forth that the price to be paid by the user
must be established by minutes of parking use without being able to charge for parking time
that has not been consumed. Law 40/2002 sets forth the duties of car park operators and their
liabilities for personal injury and property damage. In particular, according to the law, the
operator of a parking facility is liable for any damages to the vehicle and its contents.

b)    Contract with a third party (public or private body):

i.    Public contracts are typically awarded by municipalities who “own” the (car park) public
service. Although they can be formally subdivided in two different types of concessions,
the main features of both types are very similar.

       -    Public Works Concession: The concessionaire constructs and further exploits the
car park or it only operates the car park already constructed.

Those subject to the Law of Contracts with Public Authorities, a consolidated text
approved by Legislative Royal Decree 2/2000 of June 16 (“TRLCAP”) may have a
maximum term of: (i) 40 years if they are concessions for construction and
operation or (ii) 20 years if they are concessions only for the operation of the car
park.

Those subject to the current Public Procurement Law 3/2011 may have a
maximum term of 40 years.

       -    Concession for the management of a public service (which may also include
carrying out some works).


-----

Those subject to the Public Procurement Law 923/1965 may have a maximum
term of 99 years.

Those subject to the Public Procurement Law 13/1995 may have a maximum term
of 75 years.

Those subject to the TRLCAP or to the current Public Procurement Law 3/2011
may have a maximum term of: (i) 50 years if they include construction and
management or (ii) 25 years if they are concessions only for the management of
the car park.

Some of these contracts include a Public Domain Concession granted under the
Public Assets Law 33/2003, which may have a maximum term of 75 years. As a
consequence, the maximum duration for those contracts is 75 years.

ii.    Private “Concessions” comprise contracts that are signed with a private entity to build
and/or operate a car park, the contract being subject to private common civil or
commercial law and not subject to specific term constraints (nor are they derived from
the regulations on public contracts).

iii.    Management contracts comprise private contracts awarded by a public or by a private
entity. If the awarding entity is a public entity, such as AENA, regulations on public
contracts shall apply to the awarding process, but the terms and conditions under which
the contract is executed are those set out in the contract itself and, accordingly, common
civil or commercial law will apply. Thus, management contracts are not subject to any
maximum term (nor are they derived from the regulations on public contracts).

**_On-street Car Parks_**
Municipalities are the “owners” of the on-street car park public service. Thus, its operation or
management always derives from a contract awarded by a municipality. On-street car parks fall under
the following categories:

a)    Concession for the management of a public service. According to the TRLCSP, these contracts
may have a maximum term of 25 years.

b)    Service contract: The operator provides a service and receives a payment in exchange.
According to the TRLCSP, these contracts may have a maximum term of four years with a
possible extension of two additional years.

**_Legal framework_**
The construction and operation of off-street parking facilities and the provision of on-street parking
services pursuant to contracts awarded by public authorities are regulated by public procurement
regulations currently, the TRLCSP. (Contracts awarded prior to the effectiveness of the TRLCSP are
governed by the public procurement legislation in force when such contracts were awarded: Public
Sector Contracts Law, 30/2007 of October 30 (the “LCSP”), TRLCAP, Law 13/1995 of May 18, on
Contracts with the Public Authorities or Decree 923/1965, dated April 8, approving the State Contract
Law.

In addition, contracts entered into with municipalities are also usually governed by the regulation
ruling local entities services, approved by the Decree of June 17, 1955, as currently in force. In
addition, certain regions of Spain have enacted their own legislation. For example, in the Catalonian
autonomous region, Decree 179/1995 of June 13, approves the regulation of local entities works,
activities and services (“ROAS”).

In addition to the aforementioned regulations, concessions are governed by the corresponding
contractual documents which may include additional requirements to those foreseen in said
regulations, such as specific corporate requirements for the concessionaire or change of control
provisions.


-----

**_Public tender process and award_**
Concessions for the construction and/or management of public car parks, as well as for the provision
of on-street parking services, are awarded through a public tender process. In this public tender
process, interested parties may submit their bids for the contract. The specific conditions of the
contract are set forth in the terms of tender (Pliegos de Condiciones Administrativas y Técnicas) (the
“Terms of Tender”) and in the contract itself. These conditions may differ and establish particular
legal, economic and technical terms for each type of contract and for each project without prejudice
to the application of the relevant public procurement legislation in effect at the time the contract is
awarded.

**_Term and renewal of administrative concessions_**
Within the maximum term established by the relevant applicable law, each particular contract will
have the duration of the contract set out in the Terms of Tender approved for the contract.
Additionally, the contractual term may only be extended under the circumstances set out in the Terms
of Tender and within the maximum extension terms mentioned therein. However, the concessionaire
does not have a right to such an extension; the administration may grant it or not.

The regulations on public contracts are becoming increasingly stringent as far as the extension of
public concessions is concerned and so are consequently the different administrations. This new
tendency, driven by EU regulations, does not affect the duration already established under
concessions already awarded (although it may impact on the decision for granting extensions) and
will only apply to future concessions awarded after the date indicated in the Directive 2014/23/EU of
the European Parliament and of the Council of February 26, 2014 on the award of concession
contracts (“Directive 2014/23”) (i. e. April 18, 2014).

Upon expiration of the contractual term (and its possible extensions, which necessarily need to be
granted or agreed in writing) the contract is terminated. The authority will then decide whether it
wants to award a new contract in a new open tender process or if it prefers to provide the car-park
service directly itself.

**_Powers of the awarding authority_**
The awarding authority is entitled to interpret the concession contract, resolve any doubt regarding its
execution, modify it for reasons of public interest, terminate it early and determine the effects of such
termination. Decisions adopted by the awarding authority are immediately enforceable (even if the
concessionaire is allowed to challenge such decision before the tribunals and to request their
precautionary suspension).

More specifically, the awarding authority is entitled to exercise its “ius variandi”: contractual
modification carried out by the public administration for public interest reasons that may affect the
characteristics of the service provision or the tariffs to be paid by users. If the modification affects the
financial contractual regime, the administration will need to compensate the concessionaire in order
to maintain the financial balance of the concession.

**_Restoring of the economic balance_**
Public works concessions and concessions for the management of public services are subject to risk
(and venture) assumed by the concessionaire, which basically means that the concessionaire runs
the business at his own risk, including the need to carry out at his own expenses certain investments
such as technological updates, and is only entitled to request a compensation if any of the following
events occur (the administration may also initiate a proceeding to re-balance the concession for its
own benefit):

(a)   Ius variandi: mentioned above.

(b)   Factum principis: Any other action carried out by the public administration not directly modifying
the contract but which directly produces a “substantial imbalance” in the contractual economics
(for example, under certain circumstances, the opening by the same administration of another
car park which competes with the one awarded).

(c)   Unpredictable risk: Any unforeseeable event, in which none of the contracting parties
intervenes, which produces a “substantial imbalance” in the contractual economics. In these


-----

events, the “risk” is shared by both the administration and concessionaire, who will not be
entirely compensated.

(d)   Force majeure.

Compensation, which can eventually also take place in favor of the administration, may include a
modification of the tariffs to be paid by the users, the shortening or extension of the contractual term
or any other modification of the economic clauses contained in the contract.

**_Concession tariffs and other remuneration arrangements_**
The Terms of Tender and the contract establish the tariff scheme to remunerate the concessionaire.
In exchange for operating the car parks, the concessionaires are generally required to pay a fee to
the granting authority.

Usually off-street car parks are remunerated in accordance with the use of the parking spaces. Thus,
short-term parking spaces (rotación) are usually remunerated by a regulated tariff. The right of the
concessionaire to increase the tariffs to be paid by end users depends on what it is set forth in the
contract and in the Terms of Tender. Traditionally, amendments to tariffs had been linked to the
national, regional or sectorial CPI.

However, the recent Spanish Economy De-indexation Law, approved on March 30, 2015, provides
new rules for the review of monetary values in the contracts in which the public sector intervenes,
establishing a regime based on the principle of said monetary values not being modified by virtue of
price indexes or formulas that contain the same. In any event, this new regulation has no retroactive
effect and should not affect contracts awarded before its enforcement.

In addition to the tariffs for the rotary use of the car park, as an ancillary activity, the concessionaire is
in some cases allowed to sell the right of permanent use for a certain number of years of a limited
number of parking spaces to local residents for a price established in the contract, in accordance with
the Terms of Tender. Note that in some concessions there is a ratio between rotation and assignment
of use that is compulsory for the concessionaire. It is also permitted in many concessions to sell
subscriptions to users for shorter terms (monthly, weekly or daily passes, among others).

Other sources of income may be advertising within the car park, assignment of certain parking spots
to specific users such as hotels, or the implementation of ancillary activities such as car washing.
However, these additional sources of income may be limited by the Terms of Tender or even
forbidden. Note that the concessionaire may also be required to assign some parking spots to the
granting authorities free of charge as part of the contractual arrangements.

On-street concessionaires are generally remunerated through a flat fee or by reference to a
percentage of the amount collected for the provision of the service less costs. Increase of tariffs to be
paid by end users need to be authorized by the granting authority.

The Terms of Tender and the contract establish the fee scheme that the concessionaire has to pay to
the granting authority. This fee may be due with certain regularity or may be payable upfront. Failure
to comply with fee requirements is generally a cause of termination of the concession.

**_Assignment of the concessions and change of control_**
The assignment of the concession is in general, subject to the prior granting authority’s consent, to be
granted after having verified that all requirements are met. The most relevant requirement is that the
assignee shall evidence before the granting authority that it has the ability to operate the concession.

The transfer of the concessionaire’s shares (implying or not a direct change of control) is in general
not expressly foreseen in the contractual documentation or in the relevant procurement regulations.
However, in some cases, restrictions apply (e.g. obligation to notify or to obtain prior approval).

Indirect transfer of the concessionaire’s shares (indirect change of control) is in general not expressly
foreseen in the contractual documentation or in the relevant procurement regulations (e.g. port
regulations do refer to this). However, in some cases the granting authority may understand that an
indirect change of control is subject to its prior approval when it implies a change of control.


-----

This interpretation is often based on the Spanish State Council doctrine set out in its report
3375/2001, in which it considered that the transfer of a controlling stake in the concessionaire may be
considered to be a transfer of the concession, for which consent is required.

Other corporate transactions may also be subject to specific requirements.

In addition, it should be noted that concessions entered into with the City Councils located in
Catalonia are governed by the ROAS. According to the ROAS, the transfer of the shares of the
concessionaire company without the authority’s prior approval is a termination event if it implies a
change of control. Note that, as per the second transitory provision of the ROAS, this regulation
applies to administrative procedures started after its enforcement. Indeed, there is Case Law stating
that the ROAS applies also to concessions granted before its enforcement. Therefore, we cannot rule
out that some City Councils in Catalonia consider that the ROAS shall be applied also to concessions
granted before its enforcement. In addition, it cannot be ruled out that the authority considers that the
ROAS subjects the indirect change of control of the concessionaire to authorization.

Failure to comply with these requirements may lead to the termination of the concession for which the
concession will be held liable.

**_Security over concession_**
The mortgage of a concession requires in general the prior approval by the granting authority. This
authorization will be without prejudice to the second authorization which will be required upon
enforcement of the mortgage (see Assignment section above). The contractual documents may
foresee the need to obtain the granting authority’s prior approval for the placement of additional
security relating to a concession. In this regard, note that for example placing a pledge over the
compensation or other credit rights that the concessionaire is entitle to receive upon early termination
in public works concession awarded post-enforcement of Law 40/2015, of October 1, 2015, is subject
to the granting authority’s prior approval.

Failure to comply with these requirements may lead to the termination of the concession for which the
concession will be held liable and may imply the pledgee is not regarded as a privileged creditor.

**_Guarantees, insurance and other obligations with economic impact_**
Concessionaires are required to place economic guarantees before the granting authorities and
maintain them during the whole life of the concession. These guarantees respond for the obligations
that the concessionaire has vis-à-vis the granting authority. Although there is a certain freedom for the
concessionaire to choose how to place this guarantees, it is generally made by means of a bank
guarantee.

It is often the case that the Terms of Tender require that the concessionaire has certain insurance
policies in place during the whole duration of the concession, covering in general third party liability
and damages to the car parks. The Terms of Tender normally do not require these insurance policies
to be specific for a given car park, thus it allows that this requirement is met through global insurance
policies of the concessionaire.

Finally, it should be noted that the Terms of Tender may include the obligation for the concessionaire
to make specific investments either at the beginning or during the duration of the concession.

Failure to comply with these requirements may lead to the termination of the concession for which the
concession will be held liable.

**_Early termination events and consequences_**
The different regulations on public contracts (1965, 1995, 2000 and 2011) provide for certain events
that may trigger the early termination of the concession contract, each of them having particular
consequences. In general, causes of termination are: (i) extinction of the legal personality of the
contracting company; (ii) declaration of insolvency in any other proceeding of the concessionaire; (iii)
mutual agreement between the administration and the concessionaire; (iv) failure of the contractor to
provide the final guarantee or the special guarantee or complementary guarantee of the latter in time
in the cases provided for under law and the non-formalization of the contract in due time; (v) delay in
the fulfillment of the deadlines by the concessionaire; (vi) payment failure by the administration; (vii)


-----

failure to comply with other essential contractual obligations; (viii) rescue of the concession or
suppression of the service by the Administration and (ix) those causes of termination that are
expressly established in the contract.

Generally, the concessionaire has the right to be compensated under law for the following: (i) the
non-amortized value of the land, premises and equipment used for the provision of the service which
revert to the administration, and (ii) the loss of value of any other investment made in works and
installations that do not revert to the administration.

If the early termination event is attributable to the concessionaire, damages and losses caused to the
administration will need to be indemnified by the concessionaire.

Additionally, in some cases in which the early termination event is attributable to the administration,
the concessionaire is also entitled to be compensated with the loss of profits and other damages. In
certain municipalities, there is the possibility of the administration recovering the service awarded, the
so-called “rescue” of the public service or public work by the administration”, which means the
unilateral declaration of the contracting body, discretionally adopted, by which it terminates the
concession, notwithstanding the good management of the concessionaire.

**_Reversion and eventual exit payments_**
After conclusion of the concession contract the public service and/or the public works must revert to
the administration in an adequate state for its use and without any compensation.

According to the relevant municipal regulations on public contracts, the concession contract shall
determine the works and installations which will need to revert to the municipality by expiration of the
concessional term. The regulations on public contracts also provide that prior to the reversion taking
place, the administration will adopt the relevant measures so that the reversion of the works and
installations is carried out according to what is agreed in the contract. This may entail the need for the
concessionaire to carry out the relevant works or, eventually, to provide the administration with an exit
payment if the works and installations are not in an adequate state for its use. In addition, some
contractual arrangements may foresee the need to make specific payments to the authority upon
termination.

**Portugal**

**_General_**
As in Spain, in Portugal car parks may be developed either privately or through the public
concessionary regime. Similar to Spain, car parks developed through the public concessionary
regime are located on publicly owned land and involve the exercise of municipal administrative
powers relating to the regulation of traffic and local public highways. The legal regime governing car
parks developed through the public concessionary regime is more complex than that for private car
parks. Car parks developed through the public concessionary regime are managed by a private party
under an administrative concession or similar arrangement granted by a public authority, and they are
subject to the ongoing control of the public authorities that grant the concession or arrangement.

Car parks that are privately developed are usually built on privately owned land and are subject to a
less complex regulatory regime than the regime applicable to car parks developed through the public
concessionary regime. The terms and conditions applicable to privately operated car parking facilities
are contractual in nature although subject to the applicable mandatory private law provisions.
Enforceability of rights under the above mentioned agreements towards third parties may depend on
their prior registration before the competent land registry offices, notably in the case of ownership
rights, surface rights and lease agreements with a term equal to in excess of six years. Private car
park operators are generally required to obtain municipal licenses in order to build and operate the
car park and are subject to certain legislation governing the car park industry, particularly with regard
to health and safety, tariffs and consumer rights. For example, Decree-Law 81/2006, of April 20,
which regulates the use and access conditions to car parks, is applicable to privately developed car
parks.

There is no specific legislation relating to the liability of car park operators for injury and property
damage in car parks and therefore the general liability rules of the Portuguese Civil Code are


-----

applicable. According to the applicable general rules, car park operators may be liable for injury and
property damage to the extent that the damage in question results from an intentional or negligent
violation of a third party right. In off-street car parks, car park operators may also be liable for
damages caused by third parties (for example theft) in cases where the car park operator assumes
an obligation to assure the safety of the vehicles parked. However, in most cases, car park operators
explicitly exclude these obligations in the terms and conditions of use posted in the facility for
damages caused by third parties to the vehicles parked. There are court decisions recognizing the
validity of this exclusion in situations where the car operator had included such exclusion in the
conditions of use posted in the facility.

The following summary covers car parks operated through the public concessionary regime and
accordingly subject to the public regulatory regime.

**_Applicable legislation_**
The construction and operation of public parking structures and on-street parking normally takes
place under concession agreements (typically for on-street parking) or under surface rights
agreements (typically for off-street parking), usually entered into with municipalities.

The construction and operation of public parking structures and on-street parking are regulated
through the enactment of public laws which govern the formation and execution of public contracts by
municipal regulations and by contractual arrangements with municipalities.

An administrative concession is used by public authorities to promote the development of public
works by private entities that will subsequently operate such public works (a “public works
_concession”) or to contract a private entity to operate a certain public service, in principle, without_
involving any kind of construction (a “public service concession”), although some public service
concessions may imply also some construction works as an ancillary obligation.

A surface right is a right to build and maintain a certain construction for a specified period of time over
the property of the granting authority. Surface rights agreements entered into with public entities for
the construction of off-street parking facilities whilst subject to the rules applicable to the formation
and execution of public contracts as referred to above may also be subject to private law.

The concessions for the construction and management of parking facilities and on-street parking are
currently regulated in Portugal through the Public Contracts Code, approved by Decree-Law 18/2008,
of January 29 (“Public Contracts Code”). The Public Contracts Code includes provisions relating to
the formation, execution and termination of concession agreements. Prior to the Public Contracts
Code, these agreements were regulated by Decree-Laws 59/99, of March 2 (that governed public
works contracts), and 390/82, of September 17, that also imposed certain rights and obligations with
respect to any concessions granted by unicipalities. These prior laws still govern the concession
agreements which formation procedures were initiated before the Public Contracts Code was
enacted. One of the most relevant differences between the Public Contracts Code and the former
legislation with regard to administrative concessions is that, upon the enactment of the Public
Contracts Code, the duration of an administrative concession is no longer subject to a strict limitation
rule. Instead the duration of such contracts is determined in the contract in line with the period
required to amortize the investment and obtain remuneration under normal market conditions. In
addition, the concessions in the public domain are also subject to Decree-Law 280/2007, of August 7,
that sets forth the legal regime applicable to the management of public property. In some situations
the public-private partnership regulation set forth in Decree-Law 86/2003, of April 26, as amended by
Decree-law 14/2006, of July 27, or in Decree-Law 111/2012, of April 26 (which revoked Decree-Law
86/2003, of April 26), may apply.

Historically, the term limitation has caused public authorities to adopt surface rights agreements
(instead of concession agreements) in respect of off-street parking in order to allow longer duration
periods given that construction of parking facilities involves investments that could not be amortized
within such a short period of time. Surface rights are not subject to any specific term limitation.

According to the applicable rules, the construction and operation of off-street parking facilities with
respect to publicly owned land subject to the public domain legal regime (the “public domain”) should
take place under concession agreements and, conversely, the construction and operation of off-street
facilities with respect to publicly owned land not subject to the public domain legal regime (the


-----

“private domain”) could be made through surface rights agreements. In order to overcome the above
referenced term limitation applicable to concessions and due to this distinction, the general practice
adopted by municipalities has been to disaffect parcels of land from the municipal public domain and
re-incorporate those parcels in the municipal private domain precisely to allow the execution of
surface rights agreements in order to take advantage of the longer term permitted under surface
rights agreements.

Currently, the execution of surface rights agreements (in respect of public-owned properties) for the
construction of off-street parking facilities may also be subject to tender procedures established in the
Public Contracts Code (to the extent that they contain typical stipulations and characteristics of the
agreements subject to this Code) and, in addition, is subject to Decree-Law 280/2007, of August 7,
that sets forth the legal regime applicable to the management of public property. If the tender surface
right contracts are qualified as administrative contracts, then the execution regime of the Public
Contracts Code will also apply. Prior to the enactment of this legislation, the execution of such
surface rights agreements was also subject to Decree-Laws 59/99, of March 2, 390/82, of September
17, and 794/76, of November 5. These prior laws still govern older surface rights agreements which
formation procedures were initiated before the Public Contracts Code was enacted.

**_Public tender process and award_**
The public authorities enter into contracts with the private parties selected through tender processes
in which the interested parties may submit their tenders. The specific conditions of these contracts
are set forth in the Terms of Tender (“Caderno de Encargos”) and in the contract. These conditions
may differ among contracts and establish particular legal features for each specific project, while
using the aforementioned legal framework as a reference. Theoretically the grant of a surface right
could be made, according to Decree-Law 280/2007, of August 7, by direct award or through a
negotiated procedure, however, given the fact that the surface rights in question substantially contain
the typical elements of a concession, they are usually awarded through the aforementioned tender
procedures.

**_Types of contracts_**
The legislation contemplates various types of contracts. Typically, car parks may operate under three
different classes of contract: (i) a contract for concession of management of a public service without
works; (ii) a contract for concession of public works; and (iii) a surface rights agreement.

Most contracts for the operation of on-street car parks take the form of a concession for the
management of a public service without works, provided that it is not necessary to build any relevant
infrastructure for their operation.

Most of the contracts currently in force for the off-street car parks are operated under surface rights
agreements awarded by the municipalities, since, as discussed above, prior to the Public Contracts
Code’s adoption in 2008 concessions awarded by municipalities were limited to a term of 20 years.
Although even after the enactment of the Public Contracts Code the municipalities maintain the
previous trend of resorting to surface rights agreements for the off-street car parks, it is possible that
in the future car parks developed through the public concessionary regime will be more often
awarded through concession contracts.

**_Term and renewal of administrative concessions and surface rights_**
Currently, the applicable legislation does not impose a specific term limit for administrative
concessions. The law establishes that the duration shall be determined in the contract taking into
account the reasonable period of time required under normal market conditions to amortize the
investment and obtain a fair return on the investment. In the absence of such contractual clause
stipulating the duration of the concession agreement, the Public Contracts Code sets forth a 30-year
term.

Upon expiration of the agreement, the contract may not be renewed without a prior public tender
process. Nevertheless, under certain circumstances, the agreement may be extended provided that
such possibility had been contemplated by the contract, however rights and certain preference rights
for the grant of new surface rights may be deemed null and void.


-----

Surface rights agreements entered into in connection with publicly owned properties do not have a
statutory term limit but will have the term specified in the contract, in accordance with public interest
criteria and taking into account the economic balance of the service that will be operated under the
agreement. The applicable legislation does not allow the renewal of surface rights upon expiration of
the contract. Surface rights agreements normally have a long-term and, upon their expiration, a new
agreement will need to be executed following a public tender if the Public Contracts Code applies.
Otherwise, a limited, a negotiated or a direct award procedure could apply.

**_Economic-financial balance_**
In general, public contracts are executed based on the principle that the business risk is assumed by
the private entity.

Notwithstanding this, the law foresees certain situations that may lead to a modification of the terms
initially agreed in order to ensure that the public service is not affected in the face of abnormal and
unpredictable circumstances or unilateral modification of the contract imposed on public interest
grounds by the public entities. In light of the Public Contracts Code, the concessionaire or the holder
of a surface right (to the extent that such right contains typical stipulations and characteristics of the
agreements subject to the Code) is only entitled to the re-establishment of the economic balance of
the contract in the following situations:

(i)    when the circumstances upon which the parties have grounded their decision to enter into
contract suffer an abnormal and unpredictable modification imputable to the awarding authority
acting beyond the contractual frame; or

(ii)   when the agreement is modified by the public entity for public interest reasons.

According to the Public Contracts Code the means to re-establish the financial balance may be
included in the contracts. There are no legislative limits with respect to the mechanisms that may be
adopted, but often such mechanisms include revision of tariffs, adding parking spaces or a provision
stating that the authority and the concessionaire shall jointly seek an agreement to re-establish the
financial balance of the contract. In the absence of contractual provisions, the Public Contracts Code
(applicable to concessions and possibly to the surface rights agreements if the tender program
determines its applicability or because the contract is materially a concession contract) stipulates that
re-establishment of the balance shall be achieved through the extension of the contractual term,
through the revision of prices or through the payment of compensation. Any other situation involving
an abnormal and unpredictable modification of the circumstances will trigger the right to a
modification of the agreement or to receive compensation (without necessarily implying the reestablishment of the initial economic balance).

The legal framework applicable under the former laws to concessions and surface rights agreements
did not specify the rebalancing right and mechanism, at least in such detail. However, either by
appealing to general rules and principles of Law or through the use of contractual conditions
establishing the rebalance right, one could sustain such rebalancing right in similar situations and
therefore, from a practical point of view, the final applicable framework may not differ substantially
from the one currently in force.

There is no specific claim procedure prescribed by law to apply for the financial rebalancing of the
contract. Under circumstances that would trigger the rebalancing mechanism, the concessionaire or
holder of the surface right shall apply to the public entity within the contractual framework and in
accordance with the general rules applicable to contracts. In practical terms, a written notice should
be sent to the awarding entity stating the facts underlying to the request and the relevant legal
provisions and proposing the modifications required to maintain the economic balance of the contract.
Normally, this will entail a negotiation with the awarding entity. Should the latter accept the
modification or compensation proposed, this would typically be formalized by means of an
amendment to the initial agreement which would be effective as of its date of execution. In the
absence of a favorable decision or in the absence of a decision within a reasonable period of time, a
judicial claim may be filed with the administrative courts or with an arbitral tribunal in cases where the
agreement stipulates an arbitration clause, in order to obtain a ruling ordering the re-establishment of
the economic balance or the payment of compensation. The duration of a court process is difficult to
determine, as it depends on numerous factors, such as the number of appeals to be completed in
order to obtain a definitive judicial resolution (generally two appeals), or the volume of affairs


-----

affecting, in each moment, the competent court. Currently in Portugal judicial procedures in
administrative courts may last more than three years but there is no assurance the process will be
completed within this time frame.

**_Concession tariffs and other remuneration arrangements_**
The relevant Terms of Tender and the relevant contract establish the tariff scheme to remunerate the
concessionaire/holder of the surface right.

Normally with off-street structures the concessionaire/holder of the surface rights is remunerated
based on the collection of the tariffs established in the contract, which are reviewed periodically
based on the consumer price index. In addition, a fixed price or an annual amount may also be
payable by the concessionaire/holder of the surface right to the municipality in consideration for the
concession or surface right awarded.

With respect to on-street parking, normally the concessionaire agrees to deliver to the municipality a
percentage of the tariffs collected or, in some cases, a fixed amount and, in other cases, a
combination of a fixed amount plus a percentage of the tariffs. It is customary for the
concessionaire/holder of surface right to include the tariffs in its offer to tender and subsequently
propose to the awarding authority for its approval revisions of the tariffs as allowed by the contract.

**_Authorizations and change of control clauses_**
In some of the contractual arrangements, municipalities impose certain restrictions on the
shareholder of the concessionaire and the guarantees that such concessionaire can grant to third
parties, such as the need for prior authorization to create a mortgage over the concession or,
sometimes, change of control clauses.

Legislation relating to these matters does not expressly require prior authorization for share transfers
of the concessionaire or changes of control in it. Nevertheless, certain specific Terms of Tender and
contracts, or their interpretation by the awarding authority, may require prior consent for such
transactions. However, the applicable legislation expressly requires prior authorization for mortgages
or charges over assets included in the concession or over the surface right. The need for
authorization could also result from the fact that the public tender would have established
prerequisites for the qualification or the evaluation of the proposals that were met by the tenderer with
recourse of the parent company qualifications or expertise.

**_Termination of the concession_**
Under the current regulatory regime, apart from a termination resulting from contractual breaches,
concession and surface rights agreements may be terminated by the public entity as a result of the
following: (i) at any time due to public policy reasons, provided that appropriate compensation is paid
to the concessionaire/holder of the surface rights (to be calculated according to the contractual
regime or, in the absence of contractual provisions, in accordance with the law); (ii) unauthorized
assignment or transfer of the concession or surface right; (iii) unauthorized creation of mortgages or
other charges over the concession or surface right; and (iv) certain other situations specified in the
Public Contracts Code. In addition, the public entity may be entitled to assume the management of
the concession or surface right temporarily in case of severe breach of contract, such as the failure to
perform or pay amounts due. During such period the contract will be suspended and if the operation
is not resumed, the agreement may be terminated.

Contracts usually include provisions stipulating the formula that shall be used to calculate the
indemnity payable in event of early termination grounded on public interest. In general, the formulae
are designed to reflect an amount of indemnity calculated on the basis of the investment that was not
amortized and such formulae do not usually cover loss of profit, which needs to be claimed on the
basis of general principles under law. If the municipality and the concessionaire cannot agree on
compensation, the concessionaire may bring an action against the municipality.


-----

**_Liability and compensation for termination of concession contract_**
In the event of termination of the contract due to breach by the public authority, the authority will be
liable for payment of the loss and damage caused to the concessionaire/holder of the surface right.
Similarly, the termination of the contract due to intentional breach by the concessionaire/holder of the
surface right will result in such entity being liable to indemnify the authority for the loss and damage
caused. Such indemnification may be enforced initially against the guarantee created, if applicable.


-----

# Business

**Overview**
We are one of the leading concessionaires and operators of parking infrastructure in the Iberian
Peninsula, as measured by number of parking spaces and revenues. We mainly operate
underground car parks (“off-street”), as well as some parking areas on city streets (“on-street”) under
concessions and surface rights agreements from public authorities. As of June 30, 2017, our portfolio
comprised 432 contracts in 189 municipalities and other contracts with customers such as AENA and
ANA, the respective Spanish and Portuguese public airport operators, under which we manage over
522,000 parking spaces in Spain, Portugal, the United Kingdom, Andorra, France and Turkey. For the
twelve months ended June 30, 2017, our net turnover was €206.0 million, our Adjusted Revenue was
€205.7 million and our Adjusted EBITDA was €73.2 million. Our operations in Spain and Portugal,
respectively, represented 67.6% and 20.6% of our net turnover, 67.6% and 20.6% of our Adjusted
Revenue, 68.8% and 28.8% of our gross profits, 68.4% and 29.8% of our Adjusted EBITDA and
75.9% and 11.8% of our parking spaces for the twelve months ended June 30, 2017.

We have served the Iberian market since the late 1960s. We believe this has given us a “first mover”
advantage, whereby we have continually secured long-term concessions and built a portfolio of prime
parking locations in Spain and Portugal, including in city centers, airports and other high density
traffic areas, such as hospitals and business districts. Due to a variety of physical, regulatory and
other constraints such as cost of space, we believe that there is limited opportunity to develop
alternative parking options in many of these prime areas, allowing us to benefit from captive demand
with limited competition.

**Strengths**
We believe that we have several competitive advantages in the car park sector in Iberia, including our
long-term contract revenues, diversified business profile, assets with low demand risk and market
leadership. As a result of these strengths, together with the stable regulatory environment and
favorable industry dynamics, our business benefits from a high level of stability and recurring cash
flows.

**_Uniquely positioned for growth on the back of Iberia’s favorable macroeconomic trends_**
The macroeconomic environment in Spain and Portugal, our largest geographic markets in terms of
revenues, has gradually improved since 2013 and is expected to continue to improve in the
foreseeable future. The on-going macroeconomic recovery in Spain and Portugal is mainly driven by
GDP growth and a decrease in unemployment rates, with the unemployment rate in Spain expected
to be 4.5% lower in the next five years, which are the main macroeconomic factors impacting
disposable income, and therefore, retail, business traffic, petrol, and overall consumption. The car
park industry has been growing in Iberia mainly driven by this macroeconomic recovery as well as a
result of the increase in urbanization and an increase in the number of cars. The profitability of the
sector is generally improving, supported by scale efficiencies, the implementation of cost savings
programs and the utilization of innovative industry technology, among other factors. We believe that
we are well positioned to benefit from the continued improvement in the economic environment in
Iberia resulting in organic growth opportunities for us. The economic recovery in Iberia may also lead
to consolidation opportunities that provide room for further non-organic growth. We believe that
improvements in our cost savings, business activity and revenues in connection with such economic
improvement, together with our various cost efficiency initiatives, will have a positive effect on our
EBITDA.

**_Leading car park concessionaire in Iberia benefitting from scale and high barriers to_**
**_market entry_**
We are one of the leading car park concessionaires in the Iberian parking infrastructure concessions
market both by revenue and number of parking spaces. As of June 30, 2017, we managed 397,012
parking spaces in Spain, 61,897 in Portugal, 54,672 in the United Kingdom, 4,575 in Turkey, 3,258 in
France and 1,425 in Andorra. We had over 20.5 million car parking transactions in the twelve months
ended June 30, 2017, based on the number of payments made across all our car parks. In 2016, we


-----

had a market share of approximately 16% based on revenues. Our size and growth have allowed us
to achieve significant economies of scale, and the scope of our operations, combined with the various
cost management measures we have implemented, have allowed us to maintain our Adjusted
EBITDA levels. For example, our centralized system controls and manages a substantial majority of
our off-street concessions business parking facilities from a remote location, which has allowed us to
reduce headcount and personnel costs without impacting our service quality and customer
satisfaction levels. Such efficiencies have led to significant savings in operating expenses as we
reduced the number of operators per car park by more than half. In addition, our mobile maintenance
personnel is responsible for the maintenance of several car parks within a defined geographic area,
which reduces personnel expenses and standby time. This has allowed us to reallocate personnel to
perform certain functions previously outsourced, thereby reducing our reliance on third-party service
providers. Our economies of scale enable us to be a consolidation platform for smaller Iberian
parking operations, and allow us to undertake valuable new concessions and acquisitions of smaller
players. For example, when we acquired Car Parking, S.L.U. in 2014, EMSA - Empreendimentos e
Exploração de Estacionamentos S.A. (“EMSA”) in 2015 and SIENT - Sistemas de Engenharia de
Transito, S.A. (“Sient”) in 2016, we integrated each company into our centralized system to reduce
the number of staff on site, ensured maintenance works were performed by dedicated local teams
and arranged for management services relating to human resources, tax or accounting, to be
conducted by centralized management teams. In addition, through our experienced management
team and our long-standing reputation in the industry, we have been able to develop and maintain
important relationships with the various municipalities with which we do business, thereby reducing
our dependence on any single local authority or region.

We believe the upfront cost and difficulty in obtaining planning permission to build new high density
car parks in city centers, together with the favorable regulatory regime that applies to concession
agreements in Spain and Portugal as discussed under “—Stable regulatory environment with
_downside protection” below, as well as the scale required to operate car parks efficiently present_
significant barriers to entry in the car park industry. The stringent regulatory framework governing
parking concessions in Iberia reduces the risk of new competitors entering the market. For example,
due to the terms and lengths of concession contracts, competitors can be locked-out of the off-street
concessions business for long periods of time. In addition, our size provides us with the scale
required to operate a car park portfolio efficiently. For example, our scale enables us to share
resources among our car parks including maintenance and supervisory staff, as well as management
resources in respect of accounting, marketing, human resources, insurance and tax matters. The
number of our locations also gives us a commercial advantage as we are able to anticipate customer
needs across multiple locations. In addition, the high initial investment required to produce efficient IT
resources is beyond the reach of smaller competitors. Between 2014 and June 30, 2017, we invested
approximately €3.9 million in IT resources. Unlike smaller operators, we can price into our bids the
efficiencies that we can generate through our portfolio, and thus offer more attractive terms to
municipalities. Also, as there is a lack of available land in the major city centers of Iberia, there are
limited opportunities to construct new car parks, and our scale provides us with numerous
consolidation and expansion opportunities, which many smaller competitors are unable to take
advantage of.

**_High degree of diversification_**

Our business benefits from a portfolio which is highly diversified in terms of the following: number of
contracts, number of municipality clients and types of parking services we deliver. We are also diversified
through our three business lines, each of which has different risk profiles and capital requirements, but with
similar operational and managerial requirements. As of June 30, 2017, we had 432 contracts including
298 off-street concession contracts (including 84 resident contracts), 123 on-street concession contracts
(including nine tow-away contracts) and 11 off-street management contracts with customers such as
AENA, ANA, Gatwick Airport Limited (“Gatwick”) and Edinburgh Airport Limited (“Edinburgh”). Our off-street
and on-street concession contracts were granted in 189 municipalities in Iberia. Our off-street concession
business line is further diversified in terms of location, municipality, end user and type of contract (business
district, hospitals, shopping areas and tourism). We believe our limited reliance on any single contract is a
significant factor in diversifying our source of revenues and therefore reduces our cash flow volatility. While
our 10 largest off-street car parks represented approximately 12.3% of our total gross profit for the twelve
months ended June 30, 2017, our largest car park represented less than 2% of our total gross profit during
the same period. We believe our diversified business portfolio differentiates us from other infrastructure


-----

companies, who typically rely on a smaller number of larger contracts or concessions, with a greater
concentration of risk.

**_Strategically located assets with attractive concessions and limited demand risk_**

We believe that our infrastructure portfolio is well invested. Our on-street concession and off-street contract
management businesses have low demand risk because we are generally paid a fixed fee for the services
we provide, regardless of occupancy of the car park. Although our off-street concession business is subject
to demand risk and fluctuations in volumes, we believe the prime locations of our concessions will continue
attracting car park users and ensuring stable utilization levels given our car parks are located in high traffic
areas at or within close proximity to city centers. Our business was created as a result of the acquisition of
the two historical leaders in the parking concessions market in Spain and Portugal, each with prime
concessions already in place. As a result, we were able to construct car parks in strategic locations,
including Playa de la Concha in San Sebastián, Plaza Mayor in Madrid and Camões in Lisbon, and take
advantage of the existing concessions which were located within close proximity to city centers and in high
traffic areas. Therefore, we believe that we enjoy a prime position in the relevant local area with respect to
a significant proportion of our parking facilities. Moreover, the high density of city centers together with
planning regulations make the approval process for “green field” concessions difficult, effectively limiting
the supply of parking spaces in a given area. Additionally, many of our concessions in strategic locations
have a long remaining life, such as Camões, Lisbon (34 years, 340 car spaces), Playa de la Concha, San
Sebastián (41 years, 1,274 car spaces), Joan de Borbó, Barcelona (22 years, 638 car spaces) and
Restauradores, Lisbon (30 years, 545 car spaces). The prime positions of our car parks and the difficulty in
building new car parks helps to reduce the demand risk in our off-street concession business.

**_Stable regulatory environment with downside protection_**
The regulatory framework governing off-street and on-street parking concessions in Spain and
Portugal affords certain protections to the concessionaire. We and other car park concessionaires
that operate in Iberia have historically benefitted from a “rebalancing” clause under the relevant
concession legislation in Spain and Portugal, which may also apply to Portuguese public surface
rights agreements. Under certain circumstances, a change in the balance of the economic terms and
conditions of the concession that is adverse to the concessionaire will trigger a right of the
concessionaire to seek compensation or a “rebalancing” mechanism, which typically results in either
an extension of the concession period, an increase in tariffs payable by users, or sometimes an
increase in the number of parking spaces managed by the concessionaire, depending on the
circumstances. This regulatory environment has proven to be stable and predictable since the
implementation of the concession system more than 50 years ago and in the past, we have been
successful in relying on such protective legislation to seek additional compensation. Additionally, the
municipalities granting concessions have an interest in the success of public car parks since they are
a source of income for the municipality and the operation of car parks satisfies a public need.

**_Highly stable business with limited maintenance capital expenditure requirements_**
For the twelve months ended June 30, 2017, 85.8% of our Adjusted EBITDA was generated by our
off-street concessions business, which had a Weighted Average Remaining Duration of approximately
25 years. Since 2014, we have achieved a Replacement Rate of approximately 235%. Our off-street
concessions business also benefits from regulated tariffs linked to inflation. Accordingly, we benefit
from a high level of recurring business and long-term visibility of cash flows, and we believe the longterm nature of our portfolio is matched by few other infrastructure companies in Spain and Portugal.
The most significant contracts in the off-street portfolio are public concession agreements, with none
or limited rent payments, which is not the case of a typical lease contract more common in other
European countries.

We have achieved a Replacement Rate of approximately 113% since 2014 with respect to our onstreet concessions business. During the same period, we achieved a Renewal Rate of approximately
71% in respect of on-street car parks we manage. In addition, we also won a number of our
competitors’ contracts and in some instances, we have successfully renewed our on-street
concessions business despite our competitors submitting more competitively priced bids than us. We
believe this is due to our superior technical competence, including the implementation of state of the
art revenue collection technology, and our wealth of industry experience.


-----

Despite the decrease in demand and volumes within our parking facilities that we experienced during
the prior economic downturn, we were able to mitigate some of the effects through inflation-indexed
price tariffs under the majority of our off-street and on-street concessions business and off-street
contract management agreements, as well as growth in our concession portfolio and our
implementation of cost management measures. The stability of our business and the resilience of our
Adjusted EBITDA during the economic downturn are illustrated in the chart below.


**Strong operational performance – Adj. EBITDA (€mm)**


Our business model shares all the key features of infrastructure companies, such as long-term cash
flow visibility, resilient revenue generation, long-term concessions and a favorable and stable
regulatory environment with certain protections for the concessionaire in case of regulatory or
administrative change. However, unlike some other infrastructure companies (including those
operating toll roads), our car parks, once operational, require relatively low levels of maintenance
capital expenditure. Our limited maintenance capital expenditures are a result of our scale and
preventive maintenance measures and low operating intensity. On average, between 2014 and 2016,
our annual total maintenance capital expenditure totaled €2.3 million, representing 1.2% of our
Adjusted Revenue during the same period and mainly relating to the requirements of our car park
contracts, including recurring maintenance works and repairs on our car park facilities to ensure that
they remain fully operational and compliant. As a result, we believe we are well positioned to benefit
from returns on these investments without the need to make significant maintenance capital
expenditures with respect to these facilities.

We benefit from attractive working capital dynamics with low levels of credit risk with respect to our
off-street concession business, since such revenues are collected from users when they exit the car
park. Our current business does not require significant investment in working capital. For example,
our off-street concessions business line generates negative working capital because our revenues
are generally collected when earned and our costs are paid according to standard payment terms as
agreed in each of our contracts. However, our on-street and contract management businesses have
higher working capital requirements as they are more dependent on the payment terms from
contracts with public bodies. In addition, our credit risk with respect to our on-street concessions
business is primarily with the municipalities rather than private third parties. As a result of our low
maintenance capital expenditures and working capital requirements, we have achieved significant
Free Cash Flow Conversion ratios of 87.1% and 91.3% for the year ended December 31, 2016 and
the twelve months ended June 30, 2017, respectively.

Any larger capital expenditures are primarily related to the expansion of our business, including new
acquisitions and grants of new contracts and concessions. We are constantly securing new contracts
and concessions as existing contracts and concessions expire. These are based on our analysis of
investment opportunities and are typically not linked to prior commitments. Capital expenditures
linked to the expansion of the business depend upon specific requirements from newly awarded
contracts. For example, in 2016 our capital expenditures included the impact of the acquisition of the
remaining 50% stake in each of Alhóndiga, Aparcamientos de Bilbao, EMSA and Sient (€9.6 million);
the new on-street contract in Porto, Portugal (€9.7 million) and off-street concessions business capital
expenditures related to Parque Brasilia and Infanto Santo in Portugal, and Hospital Ramón y Cajal, El
Ejido and Las Terrazas de Marbella in Spain (approximately €11.1 million). Additional capital
expenditures may be required in connection with the renewal of on-street contracts nearing their
maturity date. Our limited maintenance capital expenditure requirements and high Free Cash Flow

**_Experienced management team with strong, supportive shareholders_**
Our senior management team has significant experience and understanding of the car park sector
and has an average of 14 years of experience in the industry and 12 years of experience with the
Company. Our senior management team has consistently over performed on budget targets, through
the successful integration of our businesses and significant cost savings achievements. This over
performance can also be attributed to the senior management team’s ability to anticipate and
embrace new trends and technology in the car park sector, which has enabled us to be a pioneer in


-----

the deployment of efficient improvement programs and user friendly applications, such as electronic
payment devices, license plate recognition systems and mobile applications.

In addition, our senior management team maintains strong and long-standing local relationships with
the relevant regulatory authorities in the jurisdictions in which we operate.

We also expect to derive further benefit from the experience and financial support of the Macquarie
Group following the completion of the Acquisition. The Macquarie Group, through its MIRA division, is
the world’s largest infrastructure manager by assets under management, according to IPE Real

**Strategy**
Our key strategies are the following:

**_Maintain focus on growing revenue and improving EBITDA_**
We will continue to implement measures designed to increase our revenues and thus enhance our
EBITDA and cash flows. Generally, under our concession agreements, we are subject to limitations
with respect to the maximum tariff that we can charge users of our parking facilities. As a result, we
have the flexibility to structure our pricing policy as we deem fit so long as we do not exceed the
maximum tariffs set forth in the concession agreement. Our pricing policy varies on a case by case
basis, and we may use any or all of the following pricing mechanics in order to maximize demand
and volumes: (i) season tickets, whereby we can offer a range of different products to fit our
customers’ specific needs (for example, offering specific time slots on specific days or for specific
periods of time), which can help to increase volumes during those times of the day when rotation is
less intensive, as well as have a positive impact on our working capital as a result of receiving
payments in advance, (ii) different tariff structures, whereby tariffs will differ, for example, based on
the time of day or the day of the week, and (iii) long-dated sales, whereby we can expand our product
and service offering by developing special offers and promotions designed in partnership with third
parties, such as travel agencies in connection with holiday packages or special events.

We also seek to increase revenue and volumes within our off-street concessions business parking
facilities through increased deployment of car park signage and other forms of advertising in city
centers and other high traffic areas in which our car parks are located. In addition, we anticipate that
revenues from our large parking facilities opened in the past three years will increase over the
coming years as they are currently in the “ramp up” phase. Within our on-street concession business,
we seek to continue improving our revenue collection through the implementation of best practices,
such as our integrated platform for payment (Telpark) and visual car enforcement in order to increase
revenues collected for the relevant municipality, which will thereby increase the level of variable
incentive compensation we receive under such concession. Moreover, we intend to continue to
implement technological improvements to achieve greater efficiency, which will allow us to more
efficiently manage the parking areas covered by our on-street concessions business and increase the
number of parking spaces covered per employee. For example, we plan on increasing the number of
car parks, both from our existing portfolio and new acquisitions that will be connected to our
centralized control room in order to reduce fixed costs. Upon completion of the Acquisition, we aim to
realize further net cost savings of approximately €2.3 million consisting of overhead cost savings of
approximately €3.3 million relating to the departure of top management, partially offset by €1.0 million
in additional costs we expect to incur for the appointment of a new chief executive officer and new
chief financial officer. For further information, see “Management—Empark—Transitional Services
_Agreements”._

**_Maintain our disciplined and high operational efficiency_**
We will continue to focus on managing our business in a cost-efficient manner by using the latest
industry technologies and improving customer service. We will also continue to work with car
manufacturers to implement new technology systems. In the past, we have invested in and installed
several user-friendly IT applications to enhance the customer experience at our car parks including


-----

electronic payment devices such as Via Verde, license plate recognition systems and mobile
applications, such as Telpark, for both off-street and on-street car parking. We plan to continue to
improve and extend the application of our cost-effective practices, such as monthly contract-bycontract cost base reviews, the centralization of the daily management of our off-street concessions
business car parks from a remote location, our energy efficiency programs and our on-street
efficiency programs. Furthermore we will continue to maintain our well invested assets in order to
keep our required level of maintenance capital expenditure low, and we plan to eliminate certain
overhead costs not required for continued operations.

**_Preserve and selectively expand our high quality portfolio of long-term concessions_**
We have a diversified portfolio of concessions and contracts in prime locations and will strive to
maintain and renew these concessions and contracts in order to maintain our stable cash flow
generation. We believe our infrastructure is well-invested. The total expansionary capital expenditure
for the period from 2014 to 2016 was €57.5 million. As a result, we intend to focus our efforts on
renewing our portfolio of existing concessions and contracts by maintaining our well invested assets
in anticipation of future renewal capital expenditure requirements and organically expanding our
operations by capturing new concessions and contracts. For example, due to our market leading
position, scale and expertise, we believe that we are well positioned to continue to grow our
diversified portfolio by renewing our existing contracts and concessions and capturing new contracts
and concessions from both existing customers seeking to award new concessions and from other
organizations looking to outsource the management of their parking facilities. For example, in line
with our historical strategy, we may acquire high quality smaller car parks in prime locations and to
incorporate them into our centralized control room, which will increase our portfolio of assets that
benefit from our mobile maintenance personnel. Due to our scale, long-standing experience in this
industry and established relationships with municipalities, we are able to achieve significant synergies
that also allow us to offer more competitive terms than those offered by our competitors. We believe
our position as one of the leading concessionaires of off-street concessions and on-street
concessions parking in Iberia, combined with our long-standing relationships with a diverse number of
local authorities and favorable industry dynamics, including high barriers to entry, will assist us in
continuing to implement this strategy.

**_Strategic focus on off-street concessions business in Iberia_**
We will continue to focus on managing our core business segments within Iberia, principally the offstreet segment. We may opportunistically consider dispositions of non-core operations and
geographies, in order to enhance the risk profile of investment capital expenditures and improve
profitability. In addition, as part of our long-term strategy, we may consider strategic options regarding
the on-street concession business line, off-street contract management and business outside of Iberia
in order to fully focus on our off-street concession business, which has a higher EBITDA Margin.

**Off-street concessions**
Our off-street concession business is our largest business line, representing 85.8% of Adjusted
EBITDA for the twelve months ended June 30, 2017 and having a Weighted Average Remaining
Duration of approximately 25 years. This business line primarily consists of concessions with
municipalities to operate parking facilities and underground parking facilities. Under these contracts,
we are generally required to invest in the construction of a new parking facility (a “green field”
concession) or make an upfront payment to the municipality for an existing parking facility (a “brown
field” concession). As of June 30, 2017, we had 298 off-street parking contracts (including 84 resident
contracts) under this business line, consisting of approximately 124,350 parking spaces (including
32,881 resident parking spaces) in 84 municipalities, principally in Spain and Portugal. We have a
diversified client base with our 10 largest car parks represented approximately 12.3% of our total
gross profit for the twelve months ended June, 30 2017. We also have 17 off-street contracts and
concessions in Turkey (our total net turnover from Turkey was €3.0 million, or 1.4%, of our total net
turnover for the twelve months ended June 30, 2017 in respect of our off-street concession business),
the United Kingdom (our total net turnover from the United Kingdom was €21.3 million, or 10.3% of
our total net turnover, for the twelve months ended June 30, 2017 in respect of our off-street
concession business), Andorra (our total net turnover from Andorra was €1.0 million, or 0.5%, of our
total net turnover for the twelve months ended June 30, 2017), and, since April 2017, in France.


-----

Our portfolio comprises parking infrastructure located in urban areas and other areas of high traffic
density, such as hospitals, and business and administrative centers. Due to our early entry into the
Iberian car park sector, our concessions include a number of car parks with prime locations that were
originally constructed in the 1960s and 1970s. Many of these locations are in highly transited areas
that attract a large number of visitors for a variety of purposes with limited free or paid alternative
parking options. The area of competition is limited to the perimeter around the car park thus creating
a local monopoly. Demand for our off-street parking facilities in such areas experience relatively low
volatility and have remained relatively stable even during difficult economic conditions.

Generally under off-street concessions, we design, build, finance and operate underground and multistory parking infrastructure facilities. These “green field” concessions generally require us to invest
capital to build a facility or make an upfront payment to the municipality for an existing facility in
exchange for higher potential margins and long-term concession contracts. Under our “brown field”
concessions, we also pay an annual concession fee to the municipality. Under the concession (or
surface rights agreements, in Portugal), we charge the end users a tariff (or fee) for the use of the
facility. The fees are charged either on a per minute basis for short-stay tickets or on a daily, weekly,
monthly, seasonal or annual basis under a subscription arrangement. The fees paid by end users are
specified under the concession (or surface rights agreement) and generally automatically increase
annually in line with inflation to the extent such contracts were entered into prior to the Spanish Deindexation Law entering into force on February 5, 2017. We generally retain all fees generated from
operating our off-street parking facilities and are responsible for all expenses relating to operating and
maintaining the parking facility during the term of the contract. Our off-street parking facilities are also
subject to local taxes, for which we are responsible. We also generate a small amount of income
through some basic amenities we provide to car park users within our parking facilities, such as
vending machines and car washes.

In general, our off-street parking facilities are operated on a 24-hour a day/seven-day a week basis.
Most of the features of the parking facilities are automated, including entry and exit controls and ticket
machines. Users can obtain information about subscriptions and tariffs online and over the phone.
The car parks are staffed and operated by our own employees. We have introduced a centralized
system to control and manage a substantial majority of our off-street parking facilities from a remote
location, which has allowed us to reduce personnel costs by reducing headcount while maintaining
our high quality of services and customer satisfaction levels. Such efficiencies have led to significant
savings in operating expenses as we reduced the number of operators per car park by more than
half. In addition, such measures have helped us to reduce our reliance on external service providers
by enabling us to reallocate personnel to perform certain functions previously performed by third party
service providers. We are also able to realize certain economies of scale by using our on-street
concession employees in managing our off-street operations. Routine maintenance, including painting
and cleaning, and security for our off-street parking facilities are provided by both third party
contractors and our own employees. We have achieved strong like-for-like revenue growth of 5.89%
in June 2017, reflecting year to date growth of 5.1% as of June 30, 2017. The following chart sets out
our monthly like-for-like revenues from June 2016 to June 2017.
