# Enforcement of Civil Liabilities

The Issuer is incorporated under the laws of Luxembourg and none of its directors are residents of
the United States. Furthermore, a substantial portion of the Issuer’s assets and a substantial portion
of the assets of such persons are located outside the United States. As a result, it may not be
possible for investors to effect service of process within the United States upon the Issuer or such
persons, or to enforce against them judgments of U.S. courts predicated upon the civil liability
provisions of U.S. federal or state securities laws.

If a judgment is obtained in a U.S. court against the Issuer or a Guarantor, purchasers will need to
enforce such judgment in jurisdictions where the relevant company has assets. Even though the
enforceability of U.S. court judgments outside the United States is described below for the countries
in which the Issuer and the Guarantors are located, you should consult with your own advisors in any
pertinent jurisdictions as needed to enforce a judgment in those countries or elsewhere outside the
United States.

**Luxembourg**
We have been advised by our Luxembourg counsel that the United States and Luxembourg are not
currently bound by a treaty providing for reciprocal recognition and enforcement of judgments, other
than arbitral awards rendered in civil and commercial matters. According to such counsel, an
enforceable judgment for the payment of monies rendered by any U.S. federal or state court based
on civil liability, whether or not predicated solely upon the U.S. securities laws, would not be directly
enforceable in Luxembourg. However, a party who received such favorable judgment from a U.S.
state or federal court, may initiate enforcement proceedings in Luxembourg (exequatur) by requesting
enforcement of the U.S. judgment by the District Court (Tribunal d’Arrondissement) pursuant to Article
678 et seq. of the Luxembourg Nouveau Code de Procédure Civile. The District Court will authorize
the enforcement in Luxembourg of the U.S. judgment if it is satisfied that all of the following
conditions are met:

-    the U.S. court awarding the judgment has jurisdiction to adjudicate the respective matter under
its applicable U.S. federal or state jurisdictions rules, and the jurisdiction of such U.S. court is
recognized by Luxembourg private international and local law;

-    the U.S. judgment is final and enforceable (exécutoire) in the United States;

-    the U.S. court has applied the substantive law as designated by the Luxembourg conflict of
laws rules or, at least, the court order must not contravene the principles underlying those
rules;

-    the U.S. court must have applied the proper law to the matter submitted to it and has acted in
accordance with its own procedural laws;

-    the U.S. judgment must not have been obtained subsequent to an evasion of Luxembourg law
(fraude à la loi luxembourgeoise) and must have been granted following proceedings where the
counterparty had the opportunity to appear, and if appeared, to present a defense; and

-    the U.S. judgment does not contravene international public policy or order as understood under
the laws of Luxembourg and has not been given in proceedings of a criminal, penal or tax
nature (which would include awards of damages made under civil liabilities provisions of the
U.S. federal securities laws, or other laws, to the extent that the same would be classified by
Luxembourg courts as being of a penal or punitive nature (for example, fines or punitive
damages)).

Subject to the above conditions, Luxembourg courts tend not to review the merits of a foreign
judgment, although there is no clear statutory prohibition of such review.

We have also been advised by our Luxembourg counsel that if an original action is brought in
Luxembourg, Luxembourg courts may refuse to apply the designated law (i) if the choice of such law
was not made bona fide, or (ii) if the foreign law was not pleaded and proved or (iii) if pleaded and
proved, such foreign law would be contrary to mandatory Luxembourg laws or manifestly
incompatible with Luxembourg public policy or public order rules. In an action brought in Luxembourg


-----

on the basis of U.S. federal or state securities laws, Luxembourg courts may not have the requisite
power to grant the remedies sought. Also, an exequatur may be refused in respect of punitive
damages.

Further, in the event of any proceedings being brought in a Luxembourg court in respect of a
monetary obligation expressed to be payable in a currency other than euro, a Luxembourg court
would have power to give judgment expressed as an order to pay a currency other than euro.
However, enforcement of the judgment against any party in Luxembourg would be available only in
euro and for such purposes all claims or debts would be converted into euro.

**Spain and Portugal**
Empark and certain other of the Subsidiary Guarantors are organized under the laws of Spain with
limited liability. The controlling shareholders of Empark, and the directors and the executive officers of
Empark and the other Spanish Guarantors are non-residents of the United States and a significant
portion of the assets of such persons are located outside the United States. As a result, the
enforcement in Spain of a judgment entered in another jurisdiction (other than a EU Member State),
must be made in accordance with the Spanish Law 29/2015 of July 31, on International Legal
Cooperation on Civil Matters (hereinafter, the “ILCC Law”) in connection with Article 523.2 and the
derogation provision of the Spanish Civil Procedural Law (1/2000, 7 de enero, de Enjuiciamento Civil)
(“LEC 2000”). An investor may also experience difficulty in effecting service of process on or
enforcing judgments against such persons or Empark or the other Spanish Guarantors based on civil
liability provisions of the U.S. federal and state securities laws or other laws.

We have been advised by our Spanish counsel that, at the moment, the United States and Spain are
not currently bound by a treaty providing for reciprocal recognition and enforcement of judgments.

A party in whose favor such judgment was rendered could initiate enforcement proceedings
(exequatur) in Spain before the relevant Court of First Instance (Tribunal de Primera Instancia) or the
Commercial Court (Juzgado de lo Mercantil), as the case may be. According to the ILCC Law,
recognition and enforcement in Spain of such U.S. judgment could be obtained provided that none of
the circumstances set forth in article 46 of the ILCC apply:

-    that the judgment is contrary to Spanish public policy (“órden público”);

-    that the judgment has been rendered by clearly breaching the rights of defense of any of the
parties and, in particular, if the judgment has been rendered by default of the defendant (“en
_rebeldía”), it would be deemed to breach his rights of defense if the defendant was not_
regularly and timely notified to enable it to defend itself properly;

-    that the subject matter in respect of which the judgment has been rendered falls within the
exclusive jurisdiction of the Spanish courts or, in any other matters, if the foreign court
jurisdiction does not have a reasonable connection with the dispute;

-    that the foreign judgment is incompatible with other Spanish judgments;

-    that the foreign judgment is incompatible with another country’s judgment which meets the
requirements to be enforceable in Spain; or

-    that there is an ongoing proceeding between the same parties and dealing with the same
subject which was opened before a Spanish court prior to the opening of the proceedings
before the foreign court.

According to Article 3.2 of ILCC, Law the Spanish Government may deny cooperation with other
state’s authorities if there has been a reiteration refusal of cooperation or a legal prohibition of
providing cooperation by such other state’s authorities provided that the Spanish Government passes
a Royal Decree for these purposes.

In addition, the discovery process under actions filed in the United States could be adversely affected
under certain circumstances by Spanish law (relating to communication of documents and information
of an economic, commercial, industrial, financial or technical nature to foreign authorities or persons),
which could prohibit or restrict obtaining evidence in Spain or from Spanish persons in connection
with a judicial or administrative U.S. action.


-----

Any judgment obtained against either the Issuer or any of the Spanish Guarantors in any country
bound by the provisions of EU Regulation 1215/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council
would be recognized and enforced in Spain in accordance with the terms set forth thereby (“EU
_Regulation 1215/2012”)._

The Spanish Courts may not recognize or enforce a judgment given by the courts of an EU Member
State if:

a)    it would be manifestly contrary to Spanish public policy;

b)    the judgment was given in default of appearance and the defendant was not served with
process in sufficient time and in such a way to enable it to arrange for its defense unless the
defendant failed to commence proceedings to challenge the judgment in the jurisdiction where
the judgment was rendered when it was possible for if to do so;

c)    the judgment is irreconcilable with a judgment given in a dispute between the same parties in
Spain;

d)    the judgment is irreconcilable with an earlier judgment given in another Member State or in a
third State involving the same cause of action and between the same parties and the earlier
judgment fulfils the conditions necessary for its recognition in Spain; or

e)    the party against which enforcement is sought is subject to insolvency proceedings and the
requirements established in Regulation 2016/848 and/or the Spanish Insolvency Law are not
met.

The enforcement of any judgments in Spain will be subject to article 54.4 of the ILCC Law and,
among others, the following formal requirements: (a) documents in a language other than Spanish
must be accompanied by a translation into Spanish (translator’s fees will be payable); (b) certain
professional fees are required for the verification of the legal authority of a party litigating in Spain if
needed; (c) the payment of certain court agent, lawyer and court fees and (d) the procedural acts of a
party litigating in Spain shall be directed by an attorney at law and the party shall be represented by a
court agent with the exception of enforcements of judgments issued in a proceeding in which such
direction and representation is not needed. In addition, rules governing Spanish civil proceedings
cannot be amended by agreement of the parties and will therefore prevail notwithstanding any
provision to the contrary in the Notes.

Under Spanish procedural law, process must be served personally on each defendant. The Spanish
Supreme Court, taking into account the circumstances of the case, could find that service of process
on an agent appointed by a Spanish Guarantor has infringed Spanish public policy or the rights of
defense of the Spanish Guarantors. Should this be the case, the judgment rendered in the United
States would not be recognized in Spain.

Pursuant to Article 54 of LEC 2000, the parties to an agreement are entitled to clearly submit to one
judge (juzgado) or court (tribunal) (provided that under the Spanish Procedural Law and the Spanish
Judicial Law (Ley 6/1985, de 1 de Julio, Orgánica del Poder Judicial) the relevant judge or court is
competent to solve the corresponding dispute); therefore, such article does not cover the validity of
nonexclusive jurisdiction clauses, at least for conflicts between different Spanish courts.

In the event that an action were brought before Spanish courts, a Spanish court may decide that it is
competent to hear the case even if the other party does not appear before it or appears and contests
its jurisdiction based on the fact that the Notes, Guarantees, Intercreditor Agreement or other
document is submitted to the jurisdiction of the courts of England or New York, provided, in the case
of submission to the courts of England, that the Spanish court grounds for jurisdiction is recognized
under the EU Regulation 1215/2012.

Additionally, the Spanish court will apply to the Notes, Guarantees, Intercreditor Agreement or any
other foreign law document the law chosen by the parties in the terms and with the limits provided for
in Regulation (EC) No 593/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 June 2008 on
the law applicable to contractual obligations and, namely:

a)    A Spanish court may give effect to the overriding mandatory provisions of the law of the
country where the obligations arising out of the Guarantees or Notes have to be or have been
performed, insofar as those overriding mandatory provisions render the performance of such


-----

obligations unlawful. In considering whether to give effect to those provisions, regard shall be
made to their nature and purpose and to the consequences of their application or nonapplication;

b)    A Spanish court will apply the law of Spain in a situation where it is mandatory irrespective of
the law otherwise applicable to the Notes or Guarantees;

c)    A Spanish court may refuse to apply New York or English law in relation to the obligations
incurred under the Notes or Guarantees or under the Intercreditor Agreement if such
application violates the public policy (orden público) of Spain;

d)    Where all other elements relevant to the situation at the time of the choice are located in one
or more European Union Member States, the parties’ choice of New York law shall not
prejudice the application of provisions of European Union law, where appropriate as
implemented in Spain, which cannot be derogated from by agreement;

e)    A Spanish court shall have regard to the law of the country in which performance takes place in
relation to the manner of performance and the steps to be taken in the event of defective
performance; and

f)    A Spanish Court may require evidence satisfactory to them of the New York or English law in
accordance with article 281 of the Spanish Civil Procedural Law (Ley de Enjuiciamiento Civil)
and, exceptionally if the parties have not been able to evidence foreign law, Spanish Courts
may apply Spanish law pursuant to articles 281.2 of Law 1/2000 and 33 of the ILCC.

The Courts of Spain may render judgments in a currency other than Euros. However, for the
purposes of determining the assets that need to be seized for enforcement purposes, a judgment in a
foreign currency needs to be converted into Euros at the official selling rate prevailing on the date on
which the enforcement of the foreign judgment is agreed by the Courts of the Kingdom of Spain in
accordance to Article 577 of Law 1/2000. If the currency in which the relevant judgment is expressed
is not listed in any official market, the Spanish Courts shall apply the exchange rate that they deem
appropriate pursuant to the documents that are filed with the courts by the enforcing party.

Certain of the Guarantors, including Emparque, are organized under the laws of Portugal with limited
liability. The directors and the executive officers of the Portuguese Guarantors are non-residents of
the United States and a significant portion of the assets of such persons are located outside the
United States. As a result, a final and conclusive judgment by any federal or state court in the United
States (whether or not predicted solely upon U.S. federal or state securities laws) would not
automatically be enforceable in Portugal and must be made in accordance with the Portuguese Code
of Civil Procedure.

We have been advised by our Portuguese counsel that the United States and Portugal are not
currently bound by a treaty providing for reciprocal recognition and enforcement of judgments. In the
absence of any such treaty such judgment will be recognized and enforced in Portugal according to
the procedures set out in Portuguese Code of Civil Procedure for the recognition of foreign
judgments. A final and conclusive judgment by a U.S. federal or state court would only be enforceable
in the courts of Portugal after having been reviewed and confirmed by a Portuguese court. The
Portuguese court with jurisdiction over such confirmation will be the “Tribunal da Relação” of the
judicial district where the relevant person against whom the judgment will be enforced is established.
The following requirements must be generally met - to the extent applicable: (i) there be no doubts
regarding the authenticity of the document containing the judgment, nor about the judgment’s
intelligence; (ii) the judgment be, a “condition of res judicata”, according to the laws of the U.S.,
where the judgment was rendered; (iii) that the competence of the court was not claimed fraudulently
in order to waive the applicable Portuguese laws and that the case submitted was not attributable to
the exclusive jurisdiction of the Portuguese Courts; (iv) the exceptions of “lis pendens” and of
“condition of res judicata”, cannot be argued based on a case pending or judged on a Portuguese
Court, except if the foreign court prevented the jurisdiction; (v) the defendant was duly notified to the
judgment, under the terms of the laws of the U.S., and in the judgment the adversarial nature of
proceedings was complied with, as well as the equality of the parties; and (vi) that the judgment
rendered is not incompatible with the international public policy of the Portuguese jurisdiction. This is
a judicial process that can be subject to opposition and the final court decision is also subject to
appeal.

or beneficial owner of such restricted securities or to any prospective purchaser of such restricted
securities designated by such holder or beneficial owner, in each case upon the written request of
such holder, beneficial owner or prospective purchaser, the information required to be provided by
Rule 144A(d)(4) under the U.S. Securities Act to permit compliance with Rule 144A thereunder in
connection with resales of the Notes.

We are not currently subject to the periodic reporting and other information requirements of the U.S.
Exchange Act. However, pursuant to the Indenture and so long as the Notes are outstanding, we will
furnish periodic information to holders of the Notes. See “Description of Notes—Certain Covenants—
_Reports”._

Upon request, we will provide you with copies of the Indenture, the form of the Notes and any
notation of guarantee and the Intercreditor Agreement. You may request copies of such documents
free of charge by contacting the Issuer at its registered office or contacting the office of the Registrar
in Luxembourg.

So long as the Notes are admitted to trading on the Euro MTF Market of the Luxembourg Stock
Exchange, and the rules and regulations of such stock exchange so require, copies of such
information will also be available for review during normal business hours on any business day at the
registered office of the Issuer and from the office of the Registrar in Luxembourg. See “Listing and
_General Information”._

# Listing and General Information

**Listing Information**
We will apply for the Notes to be listed on the Official List of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange and
admission to trading on the Euro MTF market of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange. Notice of any
optional redemption, change of control or any change in the rate of interest payable on the Notes will
be published in a Luxembourg newspaper of general circulation (which is expected to be the
_Luxemburger Wort) or, to the extent and in the manner permitted by such rules, posted on the official_
website of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange (www.bourse.lu).

For so long as the Notes are listed on the Luxembourg Stock Exchange and the rules of that
exchange require, copies of the following documents may be inspected and obtained free of charge
from the registered office of the Issuer or from the office of the Registrar in Luxembourg:

-    the organizational documents of the Issuer and the Guarantors;

-    our most recent audited consolidated financial statements, and any interim financial statements
published by us;

-    the Indenture (which includes the form of the Notes);

-    the Intercreditor Agreement; and

-    the Security and Guarantee Documents.

The Issuer has appointed The Bank of New York Mellon SA/NV, Luxembourg Branch as Luxembourg
listing agent, transfer agent and registrar and The Bank of New York Mellon, London Branch as
paying agent to make payments on, when applicable, and transfers of, the Notes. The Issuer
reserves the right to vary such appointments in accordance with the terms of the Indenture.

Application will be made to the Luxembourg Stock Exchange to have the Notes removed from listing
on the Official List of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange for trading on the Euro MTF Market, including
if necessary to avoid any new withholding taxes in connection with the listing.

**Litigation**
Except as disclosed elsewhere in this offering memorandum, there has been no material adverse
change in our consolidated financial position since June 30, 2017 (being the last day of the period in
respect of which the Group has published its latest financial statements) and neither the Issuer nor
any of the Guarantors is involved, or has been involved during the 12 months preceding the date of
this offering memorandum, in any litigation, arbitration or administrative proceedings which would,
individually or in the aggregate, have a material adverse effect on their results of operations,
condition (financial or other) or general affairs and, so far as each is aware, having made all
reasonable inquiries, there are no such litigation, arbitration or administrative proceedings pending or
threatened.

**No Material Adverse Change**
Except as disclosed in this offering memorandum, there has been no material adverse change in our
consolidated financial and trading position since June 30, 2017 (being the last day of the period in
respect of which the Group published its latest financial statements).

**REPORT ON LIMITED REVIEW OF INTERIM CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS**

To the Shareholders of EMPARK APARCAMIENTOS Y SERVICIOS, S.A., at the request of Management:

**Introduction**

We have carried out a limited review of the accompanying interim condensed consolidated financial Statements
(hereinafter, interim consolidated financial statements) of EMPARK APARCAMIENTOS Y SERVICIOS, S.A.,
which consists of the Interim consolidated financial statement at June 30, 2017, the consolidated income
statement, the global consolidated income statement, the consolidated statement of changes in equity, the
consolidated cash flow statement and the explanatory notes there to ( all of them condensed) for the 6-month
period then ended. The directors are responsible for the preparation of the Company’s interim consolidated
financial statements in accordance with International Accounting Standard (IAS) 34, Interim Financial Reporting,
as adopted by the European Union, for the preparation of interim financial information and for such internal
control as they determine is necessary to enable the preparation of interim financial statements that are free from
material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error. Our responsibility is to express a conclusion on said interim
consolidated financial statements based on our limited review.

**Scope of the review**

We conducted out limited review in accordance with International Standard on Review Engagements 2410,
“Review of Interim Financial Information Performed by the Independent Auditor of the Entity”. A limited review of
interim financial information consists of making inquiries, primarily of persons responsible for financial and
accounting matters, and applying analytical and other review procedures. A limited review is substantially less in
scope than an audit conducted in accordance with prevailing audit regulations in Spain and consequently does
not enable us to obtain assurance that we would become aware of all significant matters that might be identified
in an audit. Accordingly, we do not express an audit opinion on the accompanying interim consolidated financial
statements.

**Conclusion**

As a result of our limited review, which under no circumstances should be considered an audit of financial
statements, nothing came to our attention that would lead us to conclude that the accompanying interim
consolidated financial statements for the 6-month period ended at June 30, 2017 are not prepared, in all material
respects, in conformity with International Accounting Standard (IAS) 34, Interim Financial Reporting, as adopted
by the European Union, for the preparation of interim financial statements.

**Emphasis of matter**

We draw attention to the matter described in accompanying explanatory note 2, which indicates that eh
abovementioned interim consolidated financial statements do not include all the information that would be
required for complete financial statements prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting
Standards, as adopted by the European Union and therefore, the accompanying interim consolidated financial
statements should be read in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements for the year ended
December 31, 2016. This matter does not modify our conclusion.

**Restriction on distribution and use**

This report has been prepared at the request of EMPARK APARCAMIENTOS Y SERVICIOS, S.A.’s
Management exclusively in relation to the issue of bonds, the verification and registration of the Offering
Memorandum, accordingly, it should not be used by third parties or for any other purpose without our prior
written consent.

We will not accept any responsibility from any third parties different to the addressees of this report.

**1 Group activities and consolidation scope**

**_1.1 Companies forming the Group and their business_**
The EMPARK Group, hereinafter the Group, comprises the dominant company Empark
Aparcamientos y Servicios, S.A., and its subsidiaries, joint businesses and associate companies. The
registered address is: Avenida del General Perón 36, Madrid, Spain.

Through these companies, the Group engages in the following lines of business, which are its
primary reporting segments in accordance with IFRS 8.

The main business of Empark Aparcamientos y Servicios, S.A. formerly Cintra Aparcamientos, S.A.
and prior to that Ferrovial Aparcamientos, S.A. and previously Ferrevisa, S.A., is the construction and
operation of car parks under public authority concession arrangements. Said concessions stipulate
that, to fulfil the concession time frames, the car parks shall be returned to the granting entity in
perfect conditions of use, without any payment for provision of service for the Group. The
Subsidiaries carry out the same activity as the Controlling Company.

Empark Aparcamientos y Servicios, S.A., is the Controlling Company of a group of 46 subsidiaries, 6
associated and 6 JVs.

For the purpose of drawing up the interim condensed consolidated financial statements, the
assumption is that a group exists if the dominant company has one or more dependent organisations,
over which the dominant company exerts control either directly or indirectly.

Empark Aparcamientos y Servicios, S.A., the dominant company of the Group, was incorporated in
Madrid on 29 July 1986 as a public limited company. It is registered with the Company Register of
Madrid, on sheet M-53866, page 86, volume 14,090, and section 8 of the Companies Book. The most
recent adaptation and revision of its by-laws, based on the Company Register of Madrid, is registered
in volume 21,897, book 0 of section 8, page 222, sheet M-53866, and inscription no. 113.

**2 Summary of the main accounting principles**

**_2.1 Reporting rules_**
The attached Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements of Empark Aparcamientos y
Servicios, S.A. and its Subsidiaries for the six months ended on 30 June 2017 have been drawn up in
accordance with IAS 34, “Interim Financial Reporting”.

In accordance with the provisions of IAS 34, interim financial reporting is drawn up for the sole
purpose of updating the content of the latest consolidated financial statements prepared by the
Group, with emphasis on new activities, events and circumstances that occurred during the half year
without duplicating information previously published in the 2016 consolidated annual financial
statements. Therefore, for a proper understanding of the information included in these interim
condensed consolidated financial statements, they must be read in conjunction with the Group’s
consolidated annual financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2016 which were prepared
in accordance the applicable International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS).

The Group applied the IFRS-EU for the first time in financial 2009 for drafting the consolidated
financial statements.

Unless otherwise indicated, the interim condensed consolidated financial statements are reported in
euros and all amounts are rounded up to thousands of euros.

**_2.2 Accounting rules applied_**

_a) Rules and interpretations adopted by the European Union applicable in this period._
The accounting criteria employed to draw up these interim condensed consolidated financial
statements for the six months ended 30 June 2017 are identical to those applied to the recent
consolidated financial statements drawn up by the Group for financial 2016 since no new rule,
interpretation of amendment applicable for the first time during this period has had an impact on the
Group’s accounting.

At the date of preparation of these Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements the Group
has applied all the applicable IFRS and interpretations approved by the European Union (EU-IFRS)
and applicable to fiscal years beginning on or after 1 January 2017.

_b) Rules and interpretations issued by the IASB and adopted by the European Union but not applicable_
_in this period_
The Group intends to adopt any standards, interpretations and amendments issued by the IASB the
application of which is not mandatory in the European Union at the date on which these interim
condensed consolidated financial statements were drawn up, if applicable to the Group when they
come into force. The Group is currently analysing their impact. Based on the analysis carried out to
date, the Group believes that their application will not have a significant impact on its interim
condensed consolidated financial statements.


-----

_IFRS 9 Financial instruments_
In July 2014 the IASB published the final version of IFRS 9, Financial Instruments, that contains all
phases of the financial instruments project and replaces IAS 39, Financial Instruments: valuation and
classification, and all previous versions of IFRS 9. The standard introduces new requirements for the
classification and valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities, the definition of impairment and
hedge accounting. IFRS 9 indicates that it is applicable for fiscal years beginning on or after 1
January 2018 although earlier application is permitted. Retrospective application is required, but no
change to the comparative information is required. Adoption of IFRS 9 will affect the classification and
valuation of financial assets of the Group but will have no impact on the classification and valuation of
its financial liabilities. Nor will the new method of calculating impairment affect the Group. There will
be substantial changes with respect to hedge accounting, since financial hedges in effect on the
transition date of IFRS 9, which currently cannot be recognised as accounting hedges in accordance
with IAS 39, may now be recorded as accounting hedges in accordance with the new regulations.

_IFRS 15 – Income from ordinary activities deriving from contracts with clients_
IFRS 15 was published in May 2014 and establishes a new five-step model that applies to revenue
from customer contracts. According to IFRS 15 revenue is recognised for an amount that reflects the
consideration that a company expects to be entitled to receive in exchange for transferring goods or
services to a customer. The principles of IFRS 15 represents a more structured approach to valuing
and recognising income.

This new standard will repeal all previous rules regarding recognition of income. Full retroactive or
partial retroactive application is required for years beginning on or after 1 January 2018, allowing
early application. The Group is currently evaluating the impact of IFRS 15 and planning adoption by
the date indicated.

**_2.4 Comparison of information_**
Comparison of the interim condensed consolidated financial statements refers to the six-month
periods ended on 30 June 2017 and 2016 except the Condensed Consolidated Financial Position
Statements and the Statement of Changes in Net Equity, that compare 30 June 2017 with
31 December 2016.

**_2.5 Negative working capital and going concern_**
The Group had a positive working capital as of 30 June 2017 of 14,712 thousand euros and
9,648 thousand euros as of 31 December 2016. The Group also operates a centralised or
cashpooling treasury system by which Empark Aparcamientos y Servicios, S.A. manages the cash
requirements at Group level.

Moreover, the Group has credit lines and other financial resources available to meet cash
requirements (note 15).

Therefore, the Board considers that preparation of these interim condensed consolidated financial
statements based on the going concern principle, which involves the realization of assets and
liquidation of liabilities to the amounts and according to the classification with which they are recorded
in the interim condensed consolidated financial statements is appropriate.


-----

**_2.6 Accounting estimates and judgments_**
The information contained in these interim condensed consolidated financial statements is the
responsibility of the Group’s directors. The Group’s directors have made certain estimates to value
some of the assets, liabilities, revenue, expenses and commitments recorded in the interim
condensed consolidated financial statements for the six months ended 30 June 2017.

Basically, these estimates refer to:

- Evaluation of potential losses due to the impairment of certain non-financial assets.

- Recovery of assets through deferred tax.

- Provisions for major repairs, replacements and fees.

- Evaluation of possible contingencies due to legal and tax risks.

_Assessment of possible impairment losses on certain non-financial assets_
The valuation of non-current assets other than financial assets requires the use of estimates to
determine their fair value for the purpose of evaluating any potential deterioration, especially for
goodwill and intangible assets with an indefinite useful life. In order to establish this fair value, the
Company Directors estimate the future cash flows expected from the assets or the cash generating
units to which they belong and apply an appropriate discount rate in order to calculate the current
value of those cash flows. Future cash flows depend on whether budgets for the following five
financial years are met, whereas discount rates depend on interest rates and the risk premium
associated with each cash generation unit. Note 6 provides details of hypotheses used to calculate
the value in use of cash generation units, including goodwill.

_Recover of assets through deferred taxes_
Deferred tax assets are recorded for all temporary deductible differences, negative tax bases pending
compensation and deductions pending application for which it is probable that the Company will have
future taxable earnings allowing these assets to be applied. The Directors have to make significant
estimates to establish the sum of deferred tax assets which may be registered, considering the
amounts and dates on which future tax earnings will be obtained and the reversal period of temporary
taxable differences.

_Provisions for major repairs, replacements and fees_
The Group has recognised provisions amounting to 52,758 thousand euros (50,757 thousand euros
as of 31 December 2016) in non-current and current liabilities in the interim condensed consolidated
financial statements. Making assumptions and estimates regarding the discount rate and the
expected costs to be incurred is an essential part of determining the value of these provisions.

These estimates were made based on the best information available as of 30 June 2017 and
31 December 2016 on the events analysed. However, it is possible that events that may occur in the
future will require modification of these estimates, which would be carried out as required in
accordance with IAS 8.

_Evaluation of possible contingencies due to legal and fiscal risks_
The Group recognizes provisions for risks by making judgments and estimates in relation to the
probability of occurrence of said risks, as well as to determine the amount of such risks, recording the
corresponding provision when the risk is considered probable (probability greater than 50%).

**_2.7 Resource management policies_**
The Group manages its investments after a thorough review and evaluation of potentially attractive
projects from the environmental, social security and labour-related, commercial, financial and
economic points of view with the aim of achieving sustainable and balanced growth.

The Group’s shareholders seek the desired balance between the expected return on investments and
the acceptable risk when carrying out these activities.


-----

**_2.8 Consolidation policies_**
The Group closed the balance sheets of the individual financial statements of all companies included
in the scope of consolidation at the same date on 30 June 2017. Accounting homogenisation criteria
based on the accounting principles of the Controlling Company have been applied in order to ensure
homogeneous reporting of the items that comprise these interim condensed consolidated financial
statements. The interim condensed consolidated financial statements have been drawn up on the
basis of application of the following methods:

**a. Full consolidation method: All companies considered subsidiaries are fully consolidated. For**
these purposes subsidiaries are defined as companies in which Empark Aparcamientos y
Servicios, S.A. has effective control because it possesses more than 50% of voting rights directly
or indirectly by agreements with other shareholders. In assessing whether the Group controls
another organisation, consideration is given to the existence and impact of potential voting rights
which can currently be exercised or converted. Inclusion in the scope of consolidation of the Group
is carried out from the moment effective control of the subsidiary is formally established. The value
of the holdings of minority shareholders in the equity and the result of the financial year of the fully
consolidated subsidiaries is reported in the “Minority Shareholders” section of the Consolidated
Statement of Financial Position and “Result attributable to Minorities” section of the Overall
Consolidated Result Statement.

**b. Consolidation by the equity method: Associated companies are consolidated by the equity**
method. For these purposes, subsidiaries are defined as all those companies in which the group
has significant influence over management but does not exercise control or joint management with
third parties. Application of the equity method recognises the percentage of participation in the
equity of the company both in its net worth and the result of the financial year.

**c. Proportional integration method: Applies to joint ventures, which are those in which**
contractually, the management of subsidiaries is carried out jointly by the parent company and by
third parties not related with the group. The assets and liabilities assigned to joint operations or
those controlled jointly with other participants are reported in the interim condensed consolidated
financial statements classified according to their specific nature in the existing percentage holding.
The income and expenditure of consortiums are also reported according to their nature and to the
percentage holding.

**d. Balances and transactions with Group companies: Balances and transactions between Group**
companies are eliminated in the consolidation process.

**e. Conversion of financial statements in currencies other than the euro: The financial**
statements of subsidiaries and consortiums whose accounting records are in currencies other than
the euro included in the consolidation are converted at the closing exchange rate of all its assets
and liabilities with the exception of equity, which is valued the exchange rate at the time they joined
the Group. Within the consolidation process, the shares held in companies of the group are
eliminated against the shareholder equity, except in the associated companies, which are
converted at the exchange rate at closing.

The results are converted at the average exchange rate for the financial year. The difference arising
during the conversion process described above is recorded as “Conversion differences” under the
head of Net equity.

_a) Subsidiaries_
The acquisition cost method is used when accounting for the acquisition of subsidiaries. The
acquisition cost is the fair value of the assets received, equity instruments issued and liabilities
incurred or assumed at the conversion date and the fair value of any additional consideration that
depends on future events (provided it is probable and can be reliably measured).

If control is acquired in stages, the goodwill (or the negative consolidation difference) is established
for each of the individual transactions as the difference between the fair value of the holding and the
net sum attributable to the holding out of the fair value of the identifiable assets and liabilities
undertaken which are in place on that date. The identifiable assets and liabilities assumed are
consolidated on the basis of existing fair value at the time of acquisition of control, recognised under
the head of Minority Interests for the amount resulting from its participation in equity.


-----

The difference between the net sum attributable from the fair value of the assets and liabilities
acquired and in place on the date of acquisition of control and the corresponding sum on each of the
dates when the holdings were acquired gives rise to an adjustment in the reserves of the Group,
recorded net of the tax burden.

_b) Associated companies_
When the equity method procedure is first applied, investments in associated companies are valued
at the sum corresponding to the percentage represented by the holding at the time of the investment,
based on the fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities undertaken. If the resulting difference
between the cost of the stake and this value is positive, this is included in the book value of the
investment. If it is negative, the difference is recognised directly in the Condensed Consolidated
Result Statement.

Any variations experienced during the financial year in progress in the net equity of the Group
included in the Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements under the equity method,
following elimination of the proportion based on results generated in transactions between that
company and the company holding the stake, or any other group company, and not involving third
parties, increase or reduce, as applicable, the book value of the holding in question to the
corresponding proportion, following consideration of any amortisations and impairments occurring
since the method was applied for the first time.

Profits distributed by associated companies reduce the carrying value of the investment. The
harmonisation of valuation criteria and reporting periods is applied to associated investments in the
same way as for subsidiaries.

_c) Joint Ventures_
Non-realised results deriving from reciprocal transactions are eliminated in proportion to the holding,
in addition to the amounts of reciprocal assets, liabilities, revenue, expenses and cash flows.

**_2.9 Main policies applied to the Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements._**
The accounting policies used in the preparation of the Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial
Statements for the six months ended 30 June 2017 are the same as those applied in the last
consolidated annual financial statements of the 2016 financial year made by the Controlling
Company.

_2.9.1 Intangible assets_
Intangible fixed assets are initially valued at cost, either the acquisition price or production cost. The
cost of intangible fixed assets acquired by means of the combination of businesses is stated as the
fair value on the date of acquisition.

Following initial recognition, the intangible fixed assets are valued at their cost, less the cumulative
amortisation and, where applicable, the cumulative sum of recorded impairment corrections.

a) Concessions
Concessions mainly includes the fees paid on certain concessions for the operation of car parks.

These public authority concessions are recognised as assets at cost minus the cumulative
amortisation and the cumulative amount of recognised valuation corrections for impairment.

Concessions also include access rights paid by means of a concession fee during the period of the
concession. In this case the concessions are included under assets at the current value of the
minimum agreed payments without taking contingent payments into consideration.

The concessions are amortised on a linear basis over the period of the concession.

b) I.T. applications
Software licenses acquired from third parties are capitalized on the basis of the costs incurred to
acquire and prepare the specific software for use.


-----

The Company amortises its I.T. applications on a linear basis, distributing the cost of the assets over
the estimated useful life of the same, which is three years.

The costs connected with the development or maintenance of computer programs are recognised as
an expense when they are incurred. The costs directly connected with the production of individual,
identifiable computer programs produced by the Group, provided that it is considered probable that
they will generate economic benefits greater than the costs for more than one year, are recognised
as intangible fixed assets. Direct costs include the cost of the personnel developing the computer
programs and an appropriate percentage of general costs.

_2.9.2 Property, plant and equipment_
Tangible fixed assets are recognised at their acquisition cost with the addition of the costs incurred up
until their operational start-up, minus cumulative amortisation and the cumulative amount of
recognised losses.

The costs of the extension, modernisation or improvement of tangible fixed assets are charged to the
asset as an increase in its value provided they represent an increase in its capacity, productivity or an
extension to its useful life, and wherever it is possible to calculate or estimate the book value of the
items cancelled from the inventory due to replacement.

Retirements or disposals are reflected in the accounts by eliminating the cost thereof and the
corresponding accrued amortisation.

The costs of major repairs are recorded as assets and amortised over the course of their estimated
useful life, while recurrent maintenance expenses are debited to the income statements during the
financial year in which they occur.

The amortisation of tangible fixed assets, except for land, which is not amortised, is calculated in
accordance with the values of the updated cost, following the linear method based on the estimated
useful life, in accordance with the depreciation actually suffered through operation, usage and
enjoyment. The following are the estimated useful lives:

**Estimated useful life**

Buildings and other constructions.......................................................................................................  50
Machinery, installations and tools.......................................................................................................  10
Furniture and fittings...........................................................................................................................  10
Vehicles...............................................................................................................................................   6
Other fixed assets...............................................................................................................................   3

When the book value of an asset is greater than its estimated recoverable value, its value is restated
immediately at the recoverable amount.

The income and expenditure from sale of tangible fixed assets are calculated by comparing the
amount obtained by the sale with the book value and are recorded in the income statement under the
head of “Impairment and result due to disposal of fixed assets”.

The residual value and useful life of assets are reviewed, and adjusted if appropriate, at each
financial statement date.

The need to perform valuation corrections based on impairment in value is analysed at least at the
close of the financial year.

_2.9.3 Impairment losses_
In the case of goodwill, the Group carries out annual value impairment tests. In the case of
depreciable assets, at each accounting closure the Group assesses the existence of any loss in value
that forces it to reduce the carrying amount. If there is any indication of impairment the recoverable
value of the asset is calculated in order to identify the scope of the loss by impairment in case its
recoverable value is lower than its book value, and its effect is recorded in the income statement.
Impairment losses must be assessed for each individual asset. If this is not possible, the impairment


-----

loss is determined for the smallest identifiable group of assets that generates cash flows independent
of flows from other assets (cash-generating units).

The recoverable amount is the market value (arm’s length value less associated costs) or the value in
use, whichever is higher. The value in use is calculated from estimated future cash flows, discounted
at a rate that reflects the present market value, taking into account the value of money and specific
risks associated with the asset.

_2.9.4 Interest costs_
Financial expenses directly attributable to the acquisition or construction of fixed assets requiring a
period of time longer than one year in order to be fit for use are included in the cost until such time as
the asset is in operational condition.

_2.9.5 Financial assets_

a) Loans and accounts receivable:

Loans and accounts receivable are non-derivative financial assets with fixed or fixable collections and
are not listed on an active market. They are included under current assets, except those with a
maturity date beyond twelve months from the date of the consolidated financial statement, which are
classified as non-current assets. Loans and receivables are included in “Loans to companies” and
“Trade and other receivables” in the consolidated statement of financial position.

These financial assets are valued initially at fair value and then at amortised cost using the effective
interest rate. Transaction costs directly attributable to their acquisition are recognised in the
consolidated income statement. Quarterly value adjustments for impairment are made if there is
evidence that all amounts owed are not collected. The amount of the value impairment loss is the
difference between the book value of the asset and the value of the estimated future cash flows,
discounted at the effective rate of interest at the time of initial recognition. Any applicable valuation
corrections and reversion are recorded in the consolidated income statement.

The recognition and reversion of valuation corrections through the impairment of client accounts
receivable have been included under “Losses, impairment and variation in provisions through trade
operations” in the consolidated income statement.

The sums charged to the impairment account are normally cancelled once there is no expectation of
more cash being recovered.

The maximum exposure to credit risk on the date of submission of the information is the fair value of
each of the aforementioned categories of accounts receivable. The Company does not hold any
guaranty as insurance.

b) Investments in the equity of associated companies:

They are valued at their cost minus the cumulative value of value impairment corrections as required.
However, where there is an investment made prior to the classification of a company as an
associated company, the cost of the investment is assumed to be its book value prior to such
classification. Previous value adjustments recognised directly in equity are held in the same until they
are deregistered.

Investments in the assets of associated companies are included in the accounting records under both
current and non-current assets.

The current assets include short-term investment in associated companies comprising corporate
loans and other financial assets.

Non-current assets recognise the balance of long-term investments comprised of asset instruments in
associated companies. Asset instruments are broken down in the balances of holdings in associated
companies and share disbursements pending and not called.

If there is objective evidence that the book value is not recoverable, the appropriate value
adjustments arising from the difference between the book value and the recoverable amount are


-----

made, understood as its fair value minus sales costs or the current value of the cash flows deriving
from the investment, whichever is greater.

_2.9.6 Financial derivatives at fair value_
Derivatives are initially recognised at market value on the contracting date. Subsequent changes in
the market value are also recognised at each reporting date of the financial statements. The method
of identifying the profit and losses will depend on whether the instrument is classified as hedging or
not and if so, on the type of hedging. The following are the types of hedging designated by the
Group:

a) Cash flow hedging: Its purpose is to hedge the exposure to highly probable future transactions and
variations in cash flow. The gain or loss on the hedging instrument is recorded by the non-efficient
section of the consolidated result statement while the efficient part is identified directly under net
equity of the consolidated financial position statement. The amount deferred in net equity is not
recognised in the consolidated result statement until the gains or losses of hedged transactions are
recognised in result or until the maturity date of the transactions. This recognition is carried out the
same way as the results of the hedged item.

In the case of derivatives that do not qualify as hedge items, the loss or gain of said instrument are
recorded in the Condensed Consolidated Income Statement.

_2.9.7 Business combinations and goodwill_
Business combinations are accounted for using the acquisition cost method which entails recognising
the fair value of the assets and liabilities identified in the acquired business. The difference between
the cost of the business combination and the value of the identifiable assets acquired minus liabilities
assumed is recognised as goodwill, if positive, or as income in the income statement if negative. In
the acquisitions of subsidiaries, the goodwill generated is considered as increased value of the
holding. Consolidation goodwill is not amortised. Instead, the cash-generating units to which the
goodwill is assigned on the acquisition date are subject, at least annually, to review of their potential
impairment and on recognition of the associated value adjustment for impairment, if any (note 6).

Goodwill is allocated to cash generating units (CGU) with the aim of testing losses through
impairment. The allocation is made to those CGUs that are expected to benefit from the business
combination in which the goodwill arose.

_2.9.8 Inventory_
Inventories are valued at cost or their net realizable value, whichever is lower. The cost of inventories
is determined using the weighted average cost method.

The cost of finished products and products in progress, which corresponds to developments in
progress and those completed, includes costs incurred in the construction of car parks intended for
assignment of usage.

Parking spaces held for sale and included in inventories are valued at the acquisition price or
production cost.

The appropriate value restatements are made when the cost exceeds the market value and are
recognised as an expense in the income statement. If the circumstances that caused the restatement
cease to exist, the amount of the same is reverted and recognised as income in the income
statement.

_2.9.9 Cash and cash equivalents_
Cash and cash equivalents include cash in hand, deposits in banks and other short-term highly liquid
investments with a maturity not exceeding three months at the time of acquisition, which are not
subject to significant value change risks, are convertible into cash and which are part of the normal
treasury management policy of the Group.

This section includes the head of short term restricted cash flow. This concept collects the
investments of the same nature and maturity affected by financing of specific infrastructure projects,
whose availability is restricted by financing contracts as guarantee to cover specific short term


-----

obligations relative to payment of interests or principle of the debt as well as for the future
maintenance of the infrastructure.

_2.9.10 Net equity_
Ordinary shares are classified as equity. Incremental costs directly attributable to the issue of new
shares are recognised in equity as a deduction, net of taxes. Acquisitions of controlling group treasury
stock for the consideration paid including attributable related costs are deducted from equity. When
these shares are sold or subsequently reissued, any amount received net of costs is included in net
equity.

The basic earnings per share is calculated as the ratio between the net profits attributed to the
controlling company and the average weighted number of ordinary shares in circulation during said
period. The diluted earnings per share is calculated as the ratio between net income for the period
attributable to ordinary shareholders and the weighted average number of ordinary shares in
circulation during the period, since there are no equity instruments issued that may be converted into
controlling company shares.

_2.9.11 Transactions between related parties_
In general, operations among tied parties are accounted for at the initial point at their fair value. In
any case, if the agreed price differs from the fair value, the difference is recorded in accordance with
the economic reality of the operation. The subsequent valuation is made in accordance with the terms
set forth in the applicable regulations.

_2.9.12 Provisions and contingent liabilities_
Provisions for contingencies and expenses are accounted for in accordance with the estimated
amount required to deal with probable or certain responsibilities arising from legal proceedings in
progress and for compensation and pending obligations of an undetermined amount, guarantees or
other similar sureties.

Provisions are recognised when the Group has a present obligation, either legal or implicit, as a
result of past events and it is probable that an outflow of resources will be required to settle the
obligation and the amount can be estimated reliably.

Provisions are valued at the current value of the disbursements which are expected to be required in
order to settle the obligation, using a pre-tax rate which reflects the opinions of the current market as
to the current value of money and the specific risks of the obligation. Adjustments in the provision
based on any updates are recognised as a financial expense as they accrue.

Provisions maturing within one year or less and with an insignificant financial impact are not
discounted.

Contingent liabilities are possible obligations arising as a result of past events, the materialisation of
which depends on whether or not one or more future events should occur, outside the control of the
Group.

Given the activities in which the Group is currently engaged it has no liabilities, expenses, assets or
provisions and contingencies of an environmental nature which could prove significant with reference
to its equity, its financial situation and its results. Hence, specific breakdowns are not included in the
report herein on the Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements with regards information
on environmental issues.

Costs derived from the protection and improvements of the environment are attributed to the
consolidated results for the financial year in which they are incurred, irrespective of the point when
the monetary or financial flow derived from them occurs.

When such expenses involve the acquisition of property, plant and equipment the purpose of which is
to minimise environmental impact and to protect and improve the environment, these are included in
the accounts as an increase in the value of fixed assets.


-----

_2.9.13 Financial liabilities_

Debts and accounts payable

These liabilities are initially carried at the fair net value of the expenses incurred in the transaction,
subsequently recording these by their amortised cost according to the effective interest method. The
effective interest rate is the discount rate equal to the expected flow of future payments foreseeable
up until maturity of the liability. In the event that the effective interest rate is initially considered
different from the market interest, the liability is valued taking into account the actual value of the
future flows at that market rate in the case of loans with set interest rates. If said interest rate is not
fulfilled, the valuation of these is also carried out at the aforementioned market interest rate.

In the event of a renegotiation of existing debts, it is considered that no substantial modification has
occurred to the financial liability if the lender of the new loan is the same as that which granted the
initial loan and the current value of the cash flows, including the associated issuance and execution
costs using the effective interest method, varies by no more than 10% from the current value of the
cash flows pending payment on the original liability, calculated in accordance with this same method.

_2.9.14 Corporate income tax and deferred taxes_
The Group has since 1 January 2005 paid taxes under the consolidated taxation system at Cintra
Concesiones de Infraestructuras de Transporte, S.A., as a result of the change in ownership which
occurred in 2004, following which the Dominant Company fell within the aforementioned tax
consolidation perimeter. The group previously paid taxes under the consolidated taxation system as
part of the Ferrovial, S.A. Group. During 2009, as a result of the sale transaction referred, the Group
left the aforementioned tax system, and on 31 December 2009 the company applied to pay taxes as
a tax group, with effect from 1 January 2010. This group comprises the following companies:

- Empark, Aparcamientos y Servicios, S.A.

- Dornier, S.A.U.

- Femet, S.A.

- Guadianapark, S.A.

- Balsol 2001, S.A.

- Empark Infraestructuras, S.A.

- Empark Aparcamientos Andalucía, S.L.

- Maksu España, S.L.

- Car Parking, S.L.U.

- I Mas D Parking, S.L.U.

- Eospark Gestora de Participaciones, S.A.

Corporate tax expense (income) is the amount that accrues on this account in the fiscal year and
includes both the expense (income) for current tax and deferred tax.

Both the expense (income) derived from current and from deferred taxes are recorded in the
consolidated income statement. However, the taxation effect connected with items directly recorded in
the consolidated net worth statement is recognised in the net worth.

Assets or liabilities based on current tax are valued for the sums expected to be paid to or recovered
from the tax authorities, employing the regulations in force or approved and pending publication at the
date of close of the financial year.

Deferred taxes are calculated in accordance with the liability method, based on the temporary
differences arising between the taxable base sums of the assets and their book values. However,
they are not recognised when deferred taxes are the result of the initial recognition of an asset or a
liability in a transaction other than a combination of businesses which, at the time of the transaction,


-----

does not affect either the book result or the calculation base for the tax. Deferred tax is established
by applying the regulations and taxation rates approved or about to be approved at the Financial
Statement date and which are expected to be applied when the corresponding asset through deferred
tax is realised or the deferred tax liability settled.

Assets through deferred taxes are recognised to the extent that it is considered probable that future
taxable profits will be made which could be used to compensate for temporary differences.

Deferred taxes on temporary differences arising from investments in subsidiaries, associates and
consortiums are recognised, except in cases where the Group can control the timing of reversion of
temporary differences and it is probable that they will not revert in foreseeable future.

The term consolidated corporate tax includes all domestic and foreign taxes related to profits subject
to tax. Consolidated corporate tax also includes other taxes such as taxes on repatriated profits and
any other levy taken as the basis for calculating the accounting result.

The corporate tax expense reflected in the consolidated financial statements is calculated by
aggregating the expense registered for each company that belongs to the consolidated group,
increased or decreased, as appropriate, by elimination of accounting consolidation adjustments and
by the differences arising between the taxable base sums of the assets and liabilities and their book
values.

Deferred taxes are not recognised when the transaction has no effect on the book and/or fiscal value
of the assets or liabilities involved. In the case of business combinations, the corresponding deferred
taxes derived from the price assigning process and the fiscal amortisation of the generated goodwill
in each case is registered.

The assets and liabilities through deferred taxes are calculated at current taxation rates. At the date
of the Condensed Consolidated Income Statement and which are foreseen to be applicable during
the period in which the asset is realised or the liability is settled. They are debited or credited to the
income statement except when they refer to items that are directly recorded as equity, in which case
they are accounted for as debit or credit to said accounts. There is no liability by deferred taxes for
non-distributed profit of subsidiaries when the Group can control the reversion of the temporary
differences and it is not probable that these will be reverted in a foreseeable future. Deferred tax
assets and tax credits derived from negative tax bases are recognised when it is probable that the
Group may recover these in the future regardless of the time in which they are recovered and always
when the recovery is prior to the legal reversion period.

Assets and deferred tax liabilities are not discounted and are classified as a non-current asset
(liability) in the Condensed Consolidated Statement of Financial Position. The deferred taxes are
reviewed at each accounting closure.

_2.9.16 Recognition of revenue_
Revenue and expenses are attributed in accordance with the accrual principle, in other words based
on when the true value of the goods and services they represent becomes current, regardless of
when the monetary or financial value arising from them is realised.

Revenue is recorded at the fair value of the consideration to be received and represents the sums
receivable for goods delivered and services provided within the ordinary course of the Group’s
activities minus returns, rebates, discounts and VAT.


-----

The Group recognises revenue when the amount thereof can reliably be valued, it is probable that
future economic benefits will be received by the Group and specific conditions are met for each of the
activities, as detailed below. The amount of the revenue cannot be reliably assessed until all
contingencies connected with the sale have been resolved. The Group bases its estimates on
historical results, taking into account the type of customer, type of transaction and the specific terms
of each agreement.

**a) It is worth making the following distinctions within the car park business:**

a.1) Off-street and mixed parking

a.2) On-street parking (ORA)

a.3) Resident parking

a.1) Off-street and mixed parking

Off-street car park revenues are entered when the hourly parking rate is paid and, in the case of
season ticket-holders, on an accrual basis. Mixed car parks (with public and private spaces) record
revenues as follows: in the case of public spaces, in the manner described in the preceding
paragraph; and in case of private spaces, the amount received is recorded in the income statement
at the time of the transfer of concession usage of the corresponding parking spaces.

The cost of residential spaces is recognised in inventories and are transcribed to the income
statement on the date of the transfer of the concession of usage.

a.2) On-street parking (ORA)

Revenue from the ORA parking meter service is mainly based on the amount of the cost of providing
the service plus a percentage, generally between 1% and 3%, of the excess between said cost and
the funds collected. In some ORA contracts the revenue is earned at a fixed rate (service cost)
regardless of the funds collected, which are paid to the Town Council. It is recognised in the accounts
at the time the service is provided.

a.3) Resident parking

This business involves the construction of car parks whose spaces are sold directly to the end
customer during the time frame of the concession. The sales and costs are not recorded until the
parking space is delivered, which tends to coincide with the signature of the contract or, exceptionally,
with the public deed of sale.

_2.9.17 Leases_

a) When one of the Group’s companies is the lessee – Financial leasing

The Group leases certain tangible fixed assets. Leases of tangible fixed assets where the Group
substantially retains the risks and benefits derived from ownership are classified as financial leases.
Financial leases are capitalised at the commencement of the lease at the fair value of the property
leased, or the current value of the minimum payments agreed under the lease, whichever is lower.
The calculation of current value is based on the implicit interest rate of the contract, and if this cannot
be established, the Group interest rate for similar operations.

Each lease payment is distributed between the liability and financial charges. The total financial
charge is distributed over the course of the lease and attributed to the consolidated income statement
of the financial year when it accrues, applying the effective interest rate method. Contingent
payments are recorded as a cost for the financial year when incurred. The corresponding lease
obligations, net of finance charges, are included in “Financial lease payables”. Fixed assets acquired
under a financial lease system depreciate during their useful life or the duration of the contract,
whichever is lower.


-----

b) When one of the Group’s companies is the lessee – Operational leasing

Leases where the lessor retains a significant art of the risks and benefits of ownership are classified
as operating leases. Payments under operating leases (net of any incentive received from the lessor)
are charged to the consolidated result statement of the financial year when they accrue on a linear
basis over the period of the lease.

c) When the Group is the lessor

Where assets are the leased under a financial lease arrangement, the current value of lease
payments, discounted at the implicit interest rate of the contract, is recognised as an account
receivable. The difference between the gross amount to be received and the current value of this sum
for interest not accrued is attributed to the Consolidated Statement of profit or loss of the financial
year when said interest accrues, in accordance with the effective interest rate method.

Where assets are leased under an operating lease arrangement, the asset is included in the
Consolidated Statement of Financial Position in accordance with its nature. Revenue derived from the
lease is recognised in a linear manner over the course of the lease period.

_2.9.18 Redundancy compensation_
In accordance with current legislation, the Company is obliged to pay compensation to employees
who, under certain circumstances, have their employment contracts terminated. Redundancy
compensation payments which can be reasonably quantified are entered as an expense in the
financial year in which a valid expectation created by the Company exists with respect to the third
parties affected.

**_2.10 Seasonality of operations_**
The net amounts of the turnover and profit of the Group are not significantly influenced by seasonality
of operations.

**3 Management of financial and capital risks**
The Group’s activities are exposed to various financial risks: market risk (including exchange rate
risk, interest rate risk and price risk), credit risk and liquidity risk.

Risk management is controlled by the Senior Economic and Financial Management of Amsterdam,
which identifies, evaluates and pages financial risks in accordance with the policies approved by the
Board of Directors. The Board provides policies for overall risk management and for specific areas
such as exchange rate risk, interest rate risk, liquidity risk, use of derivative and non-derivative
instruments and the investment of surplus liquidity.

The financial risks to which the Group is exposed include those derived from the guarantees and
bonds required in order to undertake its activities.

During fiscal 2016 and the six months ended 30 June 2017, the Group has placed bank guarantees
with third parties and guarantee commitments to other Group companies in order to engage in its
business.

**_3.1 Market risk: Exchange rate risk_**
Management has established an exchange rate risk management policy for foreign currencies other
than the operating currency. Forward contracts, negotiated by the finance department, are used to
manage exchange rate risks arising from future trade transactions and recognised assets and
liabilities. Exchange rate risk arises where future commercial transactions or recognised assets or
liabilities are quoted in a currency other than the organisation’s operating currency.

The directors consider that this risk will not have significant impact on the interim condensed
consolidated financial statements.


-----

**_3.2 Market risk: Interest rate risk from cash flows and fair value_**
As of 30 June 2017, if the interest rates on outside resources quoted in euros had been 50 basis
points higher/lower with all other variables remaining constant, the result after taxes for the period
would have been (1,115)/1,115 thousand euros lower/higher, mainly as a result of an
increase/decrease in the cost of interest on variable-rate loans.

The Group carries out the appropriate interest rate hedges by contracting an IRS (Interest Rate
Swap). (note 14).

As of 30 June 2017 6.71% of the total financial debt balance was covered by these financial hedging
instruments.

The directors consider that this risk will not have significant impact on the interim condensed
consolidated financial statements.

**_3.3 Credit risk_**
Credit risk is handled by groups. Credit risk arises from cash and cash equivalents, financial
derivative instruments and deposits held in banks and financial institutions, along with wholesale and
retail clients including pending accounts receivable and committed transactions. With respect to
banks and financial institutions, only financial institutions that are known to be reputable and solvent
are accepted.

The directors consider that this risk will not have significant impact on the interim condensed
consolidated financial statements.

**_3.4 Liquidity risk_**
Prudent management of liquidity risk involves holding sufficient cash and transferable securities,
having access to finance through a sufficient number of agreed credit facilities and having the
capacity to unwind market positions. Given the dynamic type data from underlying businesses, the
object of the Group’s Treasury Department is to maintain the flexibility in financing by the availability
of lines of credit.

The directors consider that this risk will not have significant impact on the interim condensed
consolidated financial statements.
